description:
Favorite seafood place hands down! We got there at 4pm for HH and it's 50% off wine and $1.50 oysters. Matthew was shucking oysters and gave us the lowdown on each, which really made the experience special and felt like we were "oyster tasting." We also got the mixed mussels and clam in white wine broth with their amazing bread and were so happy. Really cute place that reminds me of a beach town restaurant. 

Also, they have funnel cake for dessert. So cool! Will definitely come again.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
There is a popular Crepevine-like place across the street. For about the same price, you can eat at Red Hill Station and have a very nice meal with excellent service in a stylish dining room. Is there really any doubt about where you want to go?

Two of us split a hamburger, which comes with a salad (we had Ceasar) AND fries, onion ring and fried dill pickle. And before all that we were given fluffy and delicious bread with olive oil and vinegar and some probably house-made green olives. 

The burger came on a homemade brioche bun. I am such a sucker for house-made bread. Sooo good.

The server split plates for us (without us asking and no charge) which was really nice of him. The portion size was huge- we couldn't finish our split meal!

My only (minor) complaint is that the kitchen was pretty slow, but I wasn't in a hurry.
author: El B.

description:
Two words...hidden gem! 

I never really walked around Bernal Heights and it's small local neighborhood. It's not huge, I mean it's at most 5 or 6 blocks but the quality of restaurants and local bodegas are awesome! A friend took me here the other day since we were in the neighborhood and recommended we stop here for happy hour. Well they have $1.50 oysters during HH and I'm NEVER saying no to that. 

So normally, HH oysters anywhere else whatever the house has on stock. Any other specific oyster is  normal price. Red Hill is $1.50 on any of the oysters on their menu. This includes Kushi, Kumomoto and other beautiful seafood gems they have on stock. Yea.....that's unheard of! We ordered a dozen for sure! 

Turns out their menu is off the charts good! All their seafood items looked great such as the squid salad and the trout tartare! We made friends to the table next to us and the lady was so sweet she gave us a taste of the squid salad! Definitely need to order that next time! Also, all their pasta is handmade fresh daily and we ordered the carbonara. Normally I don't care for cream sauces but this one was light and not too filling. The bacon they add to it cuts thru the cream with a bit of saltiness and crunch which was a good addition. 

There are other restaurants in the area that I want to try but this place hit all the marks on the menu offerings. Yes, I'll be back! Small place that does it right!
author: Andrew S.

description:
Found this little gem via Yelp (of course)

The service is great here. The staff was so helpful and very hospitable especially when they knew we were from out of town and it was our first time. 

HH starts @ 3pm and we arrived just at 3pm so it was perfect. Those $1.50 oysters and 6 dollar glasses of wine really hit the spot. 

This was our first time and last (for a while) so we had to go big or go home. You have to get their mini clam chowder pot pies. I love the pastry puff with the steaming clam chowder. It was the perfect size as well. We shared their carbonara. Cream sauce was a little bland, you just have to eat the bacon with every bite to get that kick of taste. It was still good! Also definitely big enough to share. 

Would recommend and would def come back for HH if I'm ever in the Bay Area again.
author: Brittney T.

description:
Pretty good. 

I like their happy hour. It's 3-6pm, 1.50 an oyster and I think half off wine and beer. The oysters are pretty good. 

The hot pot pie clam chowder tho! That ish is bombdiggity. It was a highly rated item on yelp and I can see why! It did take a long time for it to come out but it was good. The dough was buttery, airy and flakey(in a good way). The soup actually had a decent amount of clams and the creaminess was perfect for me. I don't like it when it's too thick but this was just right. However, I did notice it was slightly on the salty side but I didn't mind that too much. I'd still come back and get this again and again.
author: Ngoc P.

description:
Delicious place for food! 

This restaurant is small and adorable. The breeze comes in very nicely and makes the experience even more enjoyable. 

We all ordered pastas for lunch and they all tasted amazing (pesto, vongole fettucelle, and carbonara). 

I would definitely recommend this restaurant again. Pasta noodles were well made and all the ingredients are very fresh. Clams were awesome and super fat.
author: Angela L.

description:
Very expensive, oysters didn't seem fresh. Well, only the ones from Washington, the rest were fine. It was painfully quiet and the service was awkward. No one asked how my meal was... because no one really cared. 
I won't be back.
author: Pepper P.

description:
Saturday, March 31st, 2018: National Oysters on the Half Shell Day

Since my group of four loves celebrating national food days, we decided to take part in oysters! I did a Yelp search for oyster happy hours and found Red Hill Station. (Wasn't sure if there were going to be any as it was a Saturday.) We headed over and arrived around 4:45pm. We didn't have a reservation, but they had a table avail if we promised to be done by 6pm. This was just a post lunch (or brunch) / pre dinner snack, so we said yes!

They offer Happy Hour Daily, 3pm - 6pm. The specials are $1.50 oysters and 1/2 off all beer and wine on tap. The oyster selections for that day were: Shigoku, WA; Kusshi, WA; Miyagi, CA; BeauSoleil, NB. We decided to start with two dozen of all varieties. I can't recall which ones were which, but I typically like the smaller oysters the best so our last dozen were just those. In the end, we got 3 dozen HH oysters ($54).

For drinks, I decided to get beer. We had been drinking all day and it seemed like the easiest thing to drink. I wanted something light, so I went for the beer from Headlands Brewing Co, California ($4). Not sure which beer it was as they have a rotating selection on tap, but it checked the box in terms of the type of beer I wanted. I actually ended up having two pints as everyone else was nursing their one drink. The rest in our party got the following: Triennes 2016 Rose, Provence, France ($6); Giornata 2015 Sangiovese Blend, Paso Robles, California ($6); Marin Brewing Company, Point Reyes Porter ($4).

The table next to us got something fried (which smelled amazing), so we decided to order a Side of Onion Rings ($7). This was the last day of my deep fried food ban, so I couldn't try them. They did give us complimentary Olives which I had a few of. Very tasty. I think I was the only one eating them.

Good place for oyster HH with wine and beer. Great specials! This place is tiny, so make sure to make a reservation if you plan on going. It may be a wait without one. We just got lucky that day. I guess oyster and us were meant to be.
author: Elena N.

description: A solid seafood place. We started with the red trout tartare, which came with some chip type thing (although based on the menu, I was expecting more of a crostini type thing). The trout was  fresh, soft, and had some nice acidity, but was a little more of a ceviche than a tartare.  We also ordered the clam chowder pot pie and the sausage and clam pasta.  The clam chowder was solid and creamy, and the poufed pastry top was phenomenal. The pasta was rich and heavy- the sausage had a nice kick to it, but the flavors slightly overwhelmed the clam and pasta. In retrospect, our eyes were a little larger than our stomachs, and we probably would've been ok with two dishes. Overall though, everything was delicious and I definitely want to come back and try some of the other dishes.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Great place for fresh seafood.

Ciopinno - 5/5. My favorite thing on the menu. All of the seafood was cooked well and had just the right textures: the mussels and clams were soft without being too chewy, the shrimp was separated pan fried and had a light springyness to it, and the fish was very soft and buttery. Best cioppino I've had yet (granted I've only had this two or three times before), and would be my go to thing here.

Oyster dozen - 5/5. This came in four different varieties, and all of them had nice contrasting textures. Everything was fresh, and it came with three different sauces so you could put whatever you want on it.

Baked Cod - 5/5. Fish was baked just right, and had the same soft and buttery texture as the cioppino. Veggies were solid as well.

New England Chowder Pot Pie - 4/5. The pot pie makes perfect sense with the chowder, but the soup was unfortunately a little bit too salty for my tastes. Tons of clams!
author: Nevin L.

description:
Randomly came across this place on a Saturday night and it did not disappoint. About a 45 minute wait for two which wasnt too bad considering we didn't make reservations. Not much waiting space inside so you'll be stuck sitting outside in the cold if you don't have a reservation. Good for a date night or special occasion. 

Very fresh and flavorful seafood. Order the clam chowder pot pie, chefs choice oysters (we sampled three varieties & it seems they rotate) and an order of mussels. The Pesto fettuccine with scallops - one of the specials at the time - was also delicious. Scallops were perfectly seared and the pasta was all homemade. Great execution and overall dining experience.
author: Kristy L.

description: We were in the mood for seafood and found this place via Yelp reviews.  It definitely lived up to its reputation.  The food was incredible.  There were 7 of us and we shared the Red Hill Special seafood tower, and the mussels with chorizo - both of which we all would highly recommend again.  I also ordered the pasta with andouille sausage and clams - I was pleasantly surprised with the presentation and the flavor which exceeded my expectations.   For dessert, we tried one of everything and passed it around.  The dark chocolate dessert was my favorite - and paired well with the Barbara on tap which we ordered by the carafe.  It was a very fun and memorable night - and a shout out to our server Brian who was awesome and gave great service to our group.
author: Jaime N.

description: I didn't eat there, so I can't say anything about the service or interior, but the one food that I did eat was okay.  I had the Pesto Pasta with Shrimp.  The sauce was fine, but the nuts that was mixed in with the pasta didn't really do anything for me.  I think it was there to give a little textural change, but it did nothing to enhance the flavor of the dish.  Definitely should have ordered a more seafoody dish since that is what the place is known for.  If you want to come here, recommend that you don't come for the pasta and eat seafood instead.
author: Arianna C.

description:
Made reservations for 7pm on a Friday night very easily. Called in the night before...doesn't look like they have a reservation system in place...so you gotta call them! They play it old school here, people.

Anywho, small and cute date night or small group dinner spot (I'd say 4 or less). This place is known for seafood, and it was seafood we got. At a glance, there were so many good options that we decided to go share everything. 

Pot pie? Check (got the mini)! Pan seared fish? Check check (seasonal trout, not salmon). Mussel app? Checkkk (dip the bread! DELISH). Andddd pesto shrimp fettuccine - your guess? Yup, check. Pasta was perfectly al dente. But the star of the show? Seriously, their homemade bread. Seriously. It was SO good. Asked for it a few times...plus they also gave complimentary homemade(?), homegrown(?) green olives. Well marinated and delightful to start the meal with. 

All the food was topped with a carafe of sauvigion blanc, at the recommendation of our waiter. Didn't taste that great at first sip, but amazingly got better as I began to eat all the dishes. So, in the end, well played, waiter friend. 

So why 4 stars? Man, parking sucks. In the middle of Bernal and parking is a bit of a nightmare. The doors kept open the whole dinner time and let's be real, it's cold af in SF. But would I come back? Abso-freakin-lutely.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Bacon  carbonara and $1.50 3p-6p special oysters is good. Chowder pie is ok and no on the trout tartare . Service is ok, hit or miss.
author: Christy V.

description: Pretty good. Great deal for oysters! We got two rounds of oysters. Daily happy hour was great! Totally worth it. Small restaurant and the service was alright. I think our waiter was new to the role. I would definitely come back for the oysters.
author: Brittney P.

description: This is a great place for seafood, I love their oyster happy hour. But the real star of the show is their homemade bread. It has a texture unlike any bread that I've had before. It was dense and airy, with a powdery exterior that felt like the extra flour on mochi. They include a dipping tray of olives and oil and balsamic alongside it. The bread is the perfect conduit to these delicious accompaniments. Did I mention I love olives? If you're still reading this review, let me just finish and say Red Hill Station is a solid spot and if you ask for more bread, they'll gladly give it.
author: Alton Z.

description: Menu is a bit limited, but from making reservations to eating AMAZING. The staff was nice! Food was exceptional RED MEAT TROUT YUMMY YUMMY. But pesto pasta  completely over dressed toooooooooo much oil. But my boyfriend would never complain. Must visit! I will return. Suggest bring your own wine especially if your an experienced drinker. Great for couples nite out! Can't wait to try more. Thank you!
author: Tippy T.

description:
So awesome. What an absolutely great find.

Snuck in here with four of us for dinner and couldn't have been happier to find a spot. Really enjoyed some oysters as well as the hamachi crudo. Really enjoyed the mussels as well. Kids even had a really incredible burger.

This place is so sweet with great service and incredible ambience. Will be back again and again.
author: Bob K.

description:
I was specifically looking for oysters on a Saturday around lunch time and Red Hill Station popped up in my Yelp search. They do have a daily happy hour from 3 to 6pm where oysters are $1.50 each but I couldn't wait as I've been craving oysters for weeks now. 

When we walked into the restaurant, the first thing I smelled with oysters - that briny sea smell so I knew we were in the right place. 

We ordered a dozen oysters and they were perfectly chilled, so fresh and salty, and came with good ol' mignonette and cocktail horseradish sauces. I also tried the Bay Shrimp Salad and these shrimp were also very fresh and it was a heart salad with the avocado with a hint of bitterness from the grapefruit. Their burger was surprisingly good. It's a thick patty of angus beef and it's just amazing with the house made brioche bun. I recommend adding an egg. 

Service was casual yet very friendly. Our food took a bit longer to come out considering we were 1 of 2 tables in the restaurant when we ordered and the first table was already dining, almost finished with their food.

Nonetheless I just saw some Yelp photos of the Calamari Caesar Salad which looks amazing. I'll be back to try it!
author: Maya S.

description:
I'm really wrestling with how many stars to give RHS. Part of me wants to go with 2 just to keep the crowds down because THIS PLACE WAS AMAZING. Seriously. The only thing I would have done differently was to go in at 3 pm to catch their amazing happy hour specials on oysters and beverages. Live and learn.

The oysters were fresh, great and the sauces provided were wonderful. Lori got a whole crab with drawn butter that was perfect. My crocette was eggy, cheesy perfection and the salad that came with it was not some thrown together side salad. It was nuanced and sang in my mouth. All this with a beautiful white wine that brought it all together.

As other reviewers have mentioned, the marinated olives and bread they bring you on arrival are perfect. 

The service was friendly and enthusiastic. I felt like I was a guest in someone's home. 

So, yes. 5 stars and we will be back as often as possible. Lori and I agreed this place was a real find in this charming neighborhood.
author: Brian B.

description: Great food. We had the pasta with shrimp and another pasta with bacon bits. Really tasty. Also got the trout and mashed potatoes it was decent.
author: Arjan N.

description:
Ahhh Finally got to try this place! There's usually a wait, but when we went for happy hour on Monday, we didn't have to wait. 

Ambiance: casual
Happy hour: 1/2 off draft beers $1.50 oysters 
Service: excellent 
Price: reasonable 
Favorite: Grilled Calamari Salad

I definitely need to go back. Can't wait to try their carbonara
author: Gwen M.

description: My friend who lives in Bernal was nice enough to share this secret with me. I LOVE Red Hill!! We go almost weekly. The staff is so great. I'm greeted with a hug when I get there. The food is fresh and delicious. I highly recommend anything raw followed by the chowder pot pie...UGH! craving it right now! Highly recommended and great for a Sunday brunch with a carafe of wine.
author: Bjorn P.

description: Such a bummer. Came here crossed the city just for the restaurant. They should write it in here that - only accepts reservation
author: Min T.

description:
Oyster selection is good and fresh and, best of all, clean! Love the green olives and bread they start you with..

Got the hamachi tartare to start (I loveeeee hamachi) which was good, but with very strong basil. Personally not a fan of the cracker/chips they give you with the tartare though - they're not crispy and light. More like a dense cracker.
 
The pastas were delicious. They totally satisfied the craving my roommate and I had. Nicely al dente and made right in front of our eyes (since we sat at the bar facing the kitchen). The clams in my pasta were perfect - they also don't hold back on the seafood portions which is great.

Would recommend as an easy, quaint restaurant. Nothing too fancy or complicated. Intimate and cozy.
author: Nicole L.

description: I haven't been to a good place like this since I left Canada. The service is very nice and the waitresses are very patient. The food is exactly how I imagined them to be, only better. They give you 3 kinds of sauce for your oysters. Their burger is a classic order that is just perfect. I recommend going during their happy hour from 3 to 6 to try more stuff at a lower price.
author: Kalin M.

description: The only reason I rated 5 stars is there is no 6! Got lucky with 2 of the 4 bar seats without a reservation, but will make one next time. Everything about this place is wonderful and I believe Matthew really is the Rockefeller of oysters. Bravo Red Hill...Bravo!
author: Ken M.

description: Excellent happy hour with $1.50 oysters from 3-6pm daily. You get a selection of four different oysters at the happy hour price. Oysters are fresh and delicious. Our server really delved into explaining each varietal and flavor profile which I appreciated. $6 glasses of wine on happy hour are also an added bonus. Although the happy hour is limited to oysters and wine/beer, everything else as well made for a wonderful experience - friendly service, a delicious clam chowder pot pie which I highly recommend and no wait. This may be our go to oyster happy hour...it's different from Bar Crudo, but the oysters are definitely on par, plus no wait!
author: Aleyna S.

description:
5/5: food quality, location, interior design, clean restroom.

Pricey however please do not let that keep you from dining at this wonderful, tasty restaurant.
author: Kamonica C.

description:
Matthew is outstanding!  He is so knowledgeable about the oysters, not just the type, but what combination of condiments would bring out the flavors and the order to eat the variations so that we get the most out of the meal.  Thank you Matthew!

Quality of the oysters and food were excellent.  This place is a gem and definitely worth a night out.
author: Kim P.

description: Came here two nights ago for dinner. I was eager to try this place for a long time. I made reservations and we got a table for two. The place is cozy and well lit on the main drag in bernal heights. The vibe was bright, fresh and clean. The staff was really friendly and let me and my friend catch up before pushing us to order. We shared the mixed dozen oysters. They were really fresh and tasty. Then I got the mussels in the white wine sauce. The bowl was huge and the broth was delicious. They really hit the spot and left me feeling quite full. I tried a bite of my friends burger. The meat was good, the bun was soft potato bread with sesame seeds on top. I finished with a glass of Porto which was fantastic, sweet and tangy. Overall it was a good meal. I will most likely be back.
author: Anne S.

description:
I am so happy that I was able to try Red Hill Station for my birthday dinner! From beginning to end, it was a delightful experience! We arrived early so we were able to take advantage of their happy hour wine and beer on tap. Benjamin, our server, was such a doll! He went out of his way to get our party started!! We also were able to take advantage of the happy hour oysters, which were delicious and beautifully presented. After more than two dozen oysters, we ordered a salad and some fries to snack on. My daughter eats a vegan diet, and the chef went above and beyond in preparing her a delicious pasta dish that she said was one of the best meals she ever had!! I sincerely appreciated the chef's efforts to be creative, as well as Benjamin's thoughtful attitude in making sure she was accommodated. I ordered the clam chowder pot pie and it was so delicious!!! Definitely, a must try if you go here! I saw they had a mini version, but I wanted leftovers and was not disappointed when I ordered the full size--it was a very generous portion!  Benjamin brought out two mason jars (with a candle) for my birthday dessert and both were delicious--a creme brulee and an amazing fudge cake concoction! 

I just moved to this neighborhood, so I will definitely be back!! Great food, great happy hour, and most of all great service makes it all worthwhile!! Thanks, Benjamin!
author: Sheila K.

description: I've been coming for dinner ever since it opened.   Food is on point with all the freshest seafood offerings every time i come.   Awesome friendly staff.  A true neighborhood gem!
author: Cesar L.

description:
PROS:
* Great service from the staff, very attentive and friendly

*Cute place and nice decor

* Fettucine w/ Manila Clams in white wine butter sauce: This was my favorite dish and all the flavors complimented each other  very well. 

*Cioppino: I really liked this dish too, they were not stingy with their seafod. The mussels and clams were plump and meaty, and it also included alaskan cod, which was a nice touch. The soup was more on the saucy side and tasted quite similar to a marinara pasta sauce

CONS:
*Sometimes cozy means you're sitting too close to other patrons and can hear every single part of their conversation. 

*It was nearly impossible to get a hold of them to make a reservation. It took us 4 phone calls w/messages and 1 email. Go figure. Didn't help that when we finally got a real person to respond, she sounded annoyed. 

Overall, their dishes were good, not great. I wouldnt mind coming back to try their other dishes, but I'm also not in a hurry.
author: Ivy H.

description:
I don't give one star reviews to restaurants lightly. I'm a former floor sommelier and know what goes into dinner service BUT this was special.

I went in last Friday for my brothers birthday. We had my two young kids with us so we had reserved the back room months in advance. We even called and confirmed earlier in the day and told them we would get there a bit early for our 7pm reservation.

We get there at 645 and the room isn't empty (fair enough) but when we ask if it will be ready at 7 we get an answer of "they could be in there all night."

This was bad enough but they didn't apologize they were very matter of fact. Another table in the main room gets set up (I wanted to leave as my kids are small and I don't want to ruin other diners meals if they act up) and right before we sit there the room empties and we get offered that. So I take my kids back outside for 10 min as they set it up.

We get in there (30 min late) and are ready to eat. The waiter seems nice we get some wine and order. Things seem to be going up then IT happens. A cockroach runs across our table and my wife lets out a shriek.

We look in the corner and see a second one.

We tell the waiter and he says "where did it come from?" 
and "I'll tell the manager"

No manager came. No one checked in after that and everyone was done. We left full plates and got out of there. I had to hang my head into the kitchen to get my check. 

I would have made a fuss then but my brother was really bummed that his former favorite restaurant was such a shit show that I didn't want to exasperate the situation.

Good news is the pizza place next door was open so we didn't starve!!
author: Dave D.

description:
I was on the border of 4 or 5 stars.
I ordered their trout dish.

Almost immediately some olives and bread made their way to my table. I don't generally like olives but the olives that were served were excellent. The bread was some of the best restaurant bread I've had.

The trout dish itself was great. The fish was cooked perfectly, and the veggies were all delicious, but I definitely wish that it had some kind of sauce or a bit more spice especially with the mashed potatoes.
author: Lars Z.

description:
Fabulous in every way!!!!
We loved it!
Service 
Food
Atmosphere 
Everything!!!!
We found it on YElp and it lived up to the other reviews!
We will be back for sure!!!
author: Mark M.

description:
Very cute and intimate place serving fresh seafood :-)

Red Hill Station is a great casual restaurant that delivers with their food.  The open kitchen allows diners to see the skilled cooks prepare delicious meals with the various live seafood

We ordered the Red Hill Special along with the steamed mussels/clams in garlic white wine broth

Red Hill Special - Oysters, ceviche, tartare, dungeness crab, and shrimp.... special indeed.  Every seafood was extremely refreshing... the oysters with the perfect brininess and sweetness.... the ceviche with the right amount of citrus and acid.... the dungeness crab with the perfect doneness

Mussels/Clams - I'm not a huge mussels guy but i might be a convert.  Paired with the extremely flavorful broth, the mussels were pretty stellar and actually took center stage compared to the clams

Red Hill Station, i had a great first meal during my trip to SFO... i'll be back to try your desserts :-)
author: Peter H.

description:
Unbelievably good!! I've from Albany NY and in my travels, occasionally I'm pleasantly surprised by food that's really special. This is one of those times. Hands down, this was one of the best meal I've 'ever' had. I kid you not. Delicious, unique and a great presentation. The staff was knowledgeable and attentive.

Traveling on bus and having caught the fog blowing over the hills at sunset from Burnel Hill (don't miss the short hike up!) I found this packed local joint 2 blocks from my Airbnb accommodations (373 Moultrie Street, San Francisco, CA 94110 - which was terrific). I started with a half order of their Monterey calamari salad and having happened upon a seat facing the kitchen, I watched 2 chefs work in perfect choreography, intent while smiling, they enjoyed their work. I'm use to calamari, deep fried, no garnish but a lemon, usually overcooked. I'd watched the chef gingerly flipping and tending to several rolled up pieces of something... over a high flame skillet and then realized ... they were cooking my calamari! Delicious and on an elegant bed of greens, terrific. 

I sampled four oysters from different parts of the world. Catch these at happy hour and they're just $1.50 each, I paid $2.50 each. They tasted smooth and creamy.

For dinner I had the Alaskan True Cod, it flaked apart beautifully and was served over delicious mashed potatoes with the slightest hint of nutmeg, and a unique blend of exceptionally flavorful vegetables. Absolutely delicious!!

For dessert I had a funnel cake with fresh strawberries blueberries and homemade whipped cream. 

And after that gastronomical eat festival I walked up to the top of Burnel Hill Park and spotted a coyote perfectly silhouetted along the ridge line. What a night.
author: Mark R.

description: Excellent neighborhood restaurant. Great seafood and pasta. Service is spectacular. Try the carbanara. Bacon and seafood. Winnet
author: Eileen G.

description: The carbonara is excellent. New fave neighborhood restaurant. I'm determined to make their oyster Happy Hour soon!
author: Deirdre G.

description: If I have the option to give a restaurant 6 stars it will be this place. A friend of mine who used to live in the neighborhood took me to this restaurant. The staff is just amazing, the nicest people, amazing service. We ordered the octopus salad to start with, I will eat that any day, everyday. I ordered the pesto pasta with scallop, it was delicious. The home made pesto was made with perfection, the toasted almond was just the right amount and the consistency and the pasta was on point. Now that you think I already have multiple foodchasm, I tried my friend's order which is the chorizo mussels, Oh my gay! I can tell you right now that you want to order that dish, i am about to go to bed and dream about it.
author: Naoufel T.

description:
My husband and I were strolling down Cortland, hungry, on a Saturday afternoon and came upon this place. We initially eyed the burger but then two patrons passed us on their way out saying how good the seafood is. Seafood, it is! We shared some delicious oyster, my husband got their fettuccelle with scallops and I got their cod tacos. 

Everything was super fresh! I liked my husband's pasta a little more than the fish tacos, but both were good. The scallops were beautifully cooked and the pasta with pesto was really well done (and we just returned from Italy). The cod itself was really fresh and well prepared; the salad with grapefruit had a really nice dressing. I was a little less enthused by the rest of the taco, but still ate it all!

You can tell a lot of care goes into the dishes, so I look forward to trying more!
author: Lily L.

description:
Fantastic all around! The food and the vibe. 
Fresh oysters were delicious. We took the halibut salad but swapped out the fish with the seared calamari. So goooood! We also took the halibut fillet main dish which came with creamy corn and an amazing mint sauce(in the photo). So fresh! 

They have a daily happy hour from 3-6pm which we have yet to try! 

Prices aren't too bad, a bit expensive but the portions are fairly large and the food is great! 

Recommended!
author: Natalie W.

description: Great oysters, delicious pot pie, funny and charming servers, this is my go to seafood spot!
author: Byron A.

description:
We love red hill station! It's a cozy spot with excellent food. It's a casual restaurant with great ambiance. Beware that it can be quite loud inside. Also, it's an open kitchen so wear your machine washables!

Most notable are the oysters, which are only $1.50 during HH (3-6 pm). The halibut was perfectly cooked and was accompanied by an assortment of seasonable summer veggies. We also ordered the fettuccine with clams, Boston clam chowder pie and the burger, which came with salad and fries. All great!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Very nice restaurant with friendly staff who provide tasty seafood dishes and good Italian red wine.  The onion rings, trout, shrimp salad, and fish tacos are very good.  If it's your birthday they will not do anything, but ask if you want to buy a desert dish.
author: Thomas P. L.

description:
Dining in Bernal Heights has always been a hidden gem to bypass the hustle and long queues of other SF joints, and this new restaurant is a fantastic quaint seafood addition to San Francisco, that competes with the best of them. 

We made reservations 3 hours in advance with no issues and street parking was readily available in the hilly neighborhood. We were welcomed with a farmhouse meets oyster bar, a very intimate and welcoming appeal to your senses. Not overly noisy, so really nice to have a one-on-one conversation with your date/ group. Staff was 5 stars and super attentive without being bothersome. Olives and a heaping portion of bread was quickly dropped off with our red house wine creatively served in an Erlenmeyer flask as a carafe surrogate. 

With a simple daily menu, we were out to try out their oysters and anchovy salad for starters and my SO chose the tuna linguini while I selected the oyster pot pie. Oysters were fresh and refreshing. Anchovy salad was our favourite due to the crisp texture, not overly batter fried, combined with a hint of lemon/pesto that perfectly complements the greens. In line with the American way, we wanted seconds and thirds.  

Our entrees were served within a few minutes after wrapping up the appetizer. My SO's entree was the tuna linguini which was surprisingly delivered with a heaping portion of mussels and calimari. The pasta was cooked perfectly that embraced the seafood essence with delectable capers. Serving size was perfect for one. My oyster pot pie presented itself as a seafood chowder of sorts with a pastry puff/ slice of bacon pleasantly on top. It was rich and creamy, and delicious. Definitely on my list of favourite places in the city and I am looking forward to coming back over and over to fill up on my seafood cravings. The perfect date night place.
author: Pamela B.

description: I've been here multiple times and this place NEVER disappoints!  Their seafood and produce is always fresh and well made.  The service is great and the ambiance is cozy.  Even the bread and olives they put out before your meal is delicious!   I highly recommend this restaurant and have referred many clients while in the area.  Reserve a table in advance, if possible, since the restaurant is VERY small and seating is limited.
author: Linda H.

description: This was a last minute decision on our way bay to Fresno, and I'm so glad we found it. The food was superb & it was happy hour, so the oysters were half off, along with a delicious carafe of wine. All in all a great find & I hope we get to come back soon.
author: Leah T.

description: Such amazing experience! The food was delish! The server was over the top, welcoming and very polite. Truly a Jem! Thank you guys for everything I will be back for the amazing food and omg the pot pie and thank you for the bread!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Holy moly this is a MUST MUST MUST if you're in Bernal. Our family of 4 ( parents and 6 yr old and 12 year old )  had an amazing dining experience here. Wine was affordable, food was out of this world while being totally down to earth . Staff was stellar and you must ask for the red room that overlooks the kitchen working if you have foodie kids. 

Loved our server too. She was so sweet.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Called to make reservations for 2 on Saturday and the guy who answered the phone was kind enough to inform me about 1/2 off oysters til 6pm - thanks to him my friend and I came in at 530 and were able to have tons of oysters at 1/2 price. The free olives and bread they provide after you are seated were super yummy also. 

My friend got the oyster pot pie - she liked it but it was a little heavy for her, she wished she had ordered the mini. I got the trout with the almond sage butter sauce mashed potatoes and veggies - SO good! Great portion size as well, neither of us were able to finish our meal and we didn't have room for dessert. 

Overall, great experience - only downside was parking in this neighborhood is a little difficult. Otherwise, definitely recommend!
author: Nadia I.

description:
Cute, intimate restaurant in Bernal Heights that serves awesome seafood that comes as fresh as if the sea offered it. A group of friends and i went without a reservation at 6:30 PM and got seated almost immediately, right before the rush. I happened to be dining with some heavy spenders (to which I most definitely am not) so we ended up getting the Red Hill Special, and let me tell you, that was delicious! 

The Red Hill special came with a dozen oysters, four had caviar on it, dungeness crab legs, and three kinds of fish mixes (yellow tail ceviche, little bay shrimps, and tuna tartare), with different sauces to eat with it (mignonette and cocktail). The oysters were amazing, and I really loved the ceviche, which had a good balance of the acidity. We added the 500ml of white wine, a Bokisch 2015 Alvaro from Lodi, which was a good wine to pair with all the seafood. 

In addition to the Red Hill Special, the group ordered the Boston Clam Chowder pot pie (yummy!), the baked fillet (good but I was more focused on the special), and one of each of the dessert offerings- the creme brulee, chocolate pot de creme, and funnel cake. I didn't really like the funnel cake, the creme brulee was pretty standard, and the pot de creme was really rich! 

Will definitely come back to try out the cioppino, but the red hill special was super yummy! Try to make a reservation to be sure you get in, theres bread and olive oil and olives at the beginning too!
author: Larissa L.

description: Service is great as well as the mussels and oysters. But I didn't eat the fish I got coz it was bland. Nice presentation though.
author: Sherry C.

description:
One Star because they weren't able to honor the reservations I made the Friday nite before. A second star for the hostess because she was quite pleasant. Just sorry that she was put in a bind. 

I called on Friday to make reservations for Saturday nite at 7:30 for two people. My boyfriend had raved about this place after seeing it on Check Please. Took him over an hour to get to the spot from Oakland in bad bridge traffic. 

We arrived on time and waited for half an hour and still didn't get seated for our reserved table. We ended up leaving. And even after my BF mentioned to the hostess that we decided to go elsewhere, it didn't sound like our reserved table was going to open up any time soon. And in her defense she was apologetic. But who knows how much longer we would have waited had we stayed. 

It's reasonable to wait for a reserved table at a popular restaurant for 10-15 minutes. But having to wait for a reserved table for half an hour or more is beyond unacceptable.  It's poor management of the reservations process. And it's just bad business. 

I've been to plenty of restaurants in the city-- large group, table for two, reserved by phone-- where the hostess will inform me and or the large walk-in group that tables are reserved and that their time is limited. The majority of patrons are fine with that because they've been informed ahead of time and are mindful of the time. 

The hostess was very courteous, gave us regular updates and served me a great cup of coffee and even offered a blanket while we waited outside. Yes it was quite chilly outside. I realize it wasn't her fault that the bday group monopolized a bunch of tables that were reserved. But still it's just not right to have patrons who planned ahead and reserved a table wait so long. It's simply poor planning and mgmt of the reservations process and walk-in patrons. 

The restaurant website does say that they keep some tables open for walk-ins. However, I'm not so sure that system works given the capacity and popularity of the place. 

So if the restaurant can't honor advance reservations they need to get rid of the option or simply better manage the process. They've been operating long enough to have a solid system in place and to mitigate these type of situations.
author: Jessica S.

description: Food is very good, but seems a bit overpriced, even for SF. 2 pieces of fish and chips for $18??? Really??
author: M P.

description:
This is a small neighborhood type restaurant with very little ambiance, if that matters to you, and really good food.  Lots of families walking by on a Friday night with some stopping in to eat.  Parking can be a bit tricky as the streets are pretty narrow.

There's a strong seafood "scent" in the place, and that is clearly the main menu item.  We did not try the oysters that everyone else seemed to be having, but they looked good.  We started with salads - the Caesar (ok) and the Bay Shrimp salad (excellent - with a nice marinade on the shrimp, slices of grapefruit, etc. and a large portion}.  Three of our group had the cod baked with lemon and thyme.  Fish was flaky and fresh, but there was a bit too much crumb/butter topping.  Lots of mashed potato and a random vegetable.  I had the fresh crab - delicious.  Cracked and partially cleaned in a bowl that allowed lots of room for digging out out all that good stuff.   Accompanied by lemon and butter - doesn't get much better.  Nothing came with it in terms of veggies, so I was glad I had had the salad.  Bread was excellent and we love our bread.  We had a lovely bottle of Sancerre with the meal.

Service was friendly and attentive after an early rough moment (which we could not figure out).  All in all, a really good place for a meal if you're looking for casual, low key but good food.
author: Karne N.

description: Can't recommend this place enough. We got the chorizo steamer with muscles, 18 oysters, and tartare. All of it was excellent. The wait staff was very friendly and the proseco good. The complimentary sourdough bread and olives were great too! We are visiting San Fransisco for just 4 days and may go back!
author: Hari S.

description:
I usually don't like going out for pasta or seafood because I feel like it is overpriced for something I can either make at home or get for cheaper and better at a Chinese restaurant (I really only like cooked fish at Chinese restaurants). But, I had a really good dinner experience here! We shared the clams and mussels appetizer, and of course had to keep asking for more bread to soak up that delicious broth. I had the vongole, and despite having filled up on bread, finished my entire plate because it was just SO good. So many clams and there was some sort of bread crumb or crunchy topping on the pasta that just added the perfect touch. Even though it was expensive at $24, the quality was definitely there and you do get a hefty portion of noodles and clams. I had a bite of my friend's carbonara, and while the noodles were good, I wasn't a fan of the bacon which was too soft and fatty.

This is a great place for a date or a small group looking for a nicer meal. Even though it's advertised as a seafood restaurant, definitely go for one of the pastas!
author: Kathy L.

description:
Posting this while waiting for the check.
It's 2/20/2017 at around 1pm 4people order 3 burgers and 1 egg/chorizo taco plate. 

We waited 30 mins for 3 burger which were all over salted. We provided feedback to the wait staff and did get comp'd for all three burgers. 

Reason for the 3 stars was cause of the wait and when we provided feedback to the lady her response was a surprising "well I didn't make the food".... Shame
author: Gary C.

description: Primarily this review is for their awesome HH. The portions, quality and overall good vibe this HH gives off in spades make it a must try. Beer/Wine Half price, $1.5 Oysters, delicious bread...I literally need nothing else. If you're WFH or just down to relax with friends over good food and drink, this is your place.
author: Darin E.

description:
What a gem! We had a friend from London in town and had taken him for dinner at a loud and trendy restaurant place in North Beach the night before: no bueno. For the second evening we were determined to go to a place that feels more San Francisco to us and so we spent some time browsing on Yelp...looking for a place that ticked the following boxes: neighborhoody, casual, intimate, inventive food and reasonable prices. That's when we stumbled upon Red Hill Station.

When we arrived the staff greeted us warmly. We didn't have a reservation but since it was early (6pm), we got seated straight away...phew! I liked that you could see into the kitchen were the cooks were swinging flaming pans: that promised to be good. I ordered the calamari caesar and the cod tacos. The former was absolutely delicious and the latter was nice, yet was a bit messy overall. My dining companions ordered the Vongole and the halibut, respectively. We drank local beer from the tap, which was nice and unpretentious. 

Overall, this place was exactly what we were looking for and it left our visitor with the right impression of San Francisco!
author: Uli B.

description:
The reason for the one star review is that I was just charged $26 for 11 mussels. My husband ordered the cod and it was cheaper and came with more. I think it's absurd to charge 26 bucks + tax   and at least not tell ppl what to expect. It appears as a main - but for sure leaving here hungry. Our waitress was really nice and asked if I wanted to order anything else- and the answer is yes, but guess what I don't want to pay another 15 or 30 dollars so our bill ends up being crazy. 

Would have loved if they offered to do anything for the confusion but no they didn't. I get it it's San Francisco but come on we're not all rich. Really leaving here disappointed but more than anything leaving hungry. I could have had a steak dinner for $26 dollars.
author: Vanessa F.

description: If you're in Bernal Heights (hidden San Francisco area  with great views from Bernal Heights Park and cool random shops on Cortland Avenue), then Red Hill Station a great place to eat a late lunch--its open all day. Absolutely fantastic pasta : Andouille sausage, Manila clams, white wine, garlic, lemon, herbs , huge portions that you can easily split. Great seafood, small space with good service.
author: Laura D.

description:
+ nice ambiance
+ happy hours on weekends between 4-6pm ($1.50 oysters)
+ clam chowder pot pie - the dough was soft yet crispy; the clam chowder was super good; I still think that $18 is a lot of a bowl of chowder with a piece of dough layered on top - but it was very good
+ Dungeness crab - a bit overpriced but the crab had a ton of meet
author: Margaret R.

description:
I have found my monthly seafood spot, and fortunately a short drive away.

My brunch date had cancelled so reached out to my backup buddy plan. Offered him something in Noe Valley (Basic) or something in Bernal Heights. We were both ready to rock Bernal Heights, and even though I'm down the road, sadly haven't explored this area enough. And even though I'm closer, he got there early.

The place is cute - a main dining area with about 8 tables, 4+ on each wall, and even a private dining room upstairs. The kitchen is visible the to the whole restaurant, and you can see and tell everything is made to order.

My buddy and I wanted to try everything, and we used the couple sitting next to us for advice. I mean, I love seafood pasta, the shrimp melt sounded good, and even the fish and chips have good reviews. As two hungry men, we decided to just share everything and had no major complaints.

-Red Trout Tartare: this came out more like a ceviche, lemon juice and oil, all. But it was a lot of trout and was absolutely delicious. Would definitely get this again.
-Monterrey Bay Squid Salad: to explain how good this was, the last couple to come in both got one for themselves. Grilled and seasoned perfectly, the squidlets and meat were great. Again, must get.
-Clam Chowder Pot Pie. This was the weakest of the three dishes, but was still good. Also took the longest time, so clearly was made to order. See, for me clam chowder has to pass the spoon test - you put your spoon straight in, and if it stays standing up, you have a real chowdah! This was a watery broth, and with the pie crush, was probably the sweetest clam chowder I've had. But there were good pieces of clam inside.

There was more I'd love to try, like the cioppino, the pastas, and even the mussels. They also do dessert, but we were pretty full at that point.

I'd also like to point out that the staff were wonderful. The waiter genuinely came across as loving his job, and trying to get the best meal to his customers. He constantly kept us updated on the status of our food, and was willing to answer any questions we had. It also wasn't badly priced - between these three plates, split ticket was around $30. For all the seafood, and being full, was well worth it.
author: Michael C.

description: Truly quintessential San Francisco!  In the midst of too many restaurants becoming part of a large corporate plan or top spots being monopolized by the homogenized food industry this is truly a breath of fresh air and a bite of heaven.  Just an original neighborhood joint staffed by people who love what they do and it shows.  Honestly one of the best meals in a long time.  We had very simple dishes but that were masterfully prepared. Ciopino where nothing was over cooked and the tomato base was bursting with fresh flavor in every bite. Scallops perfectly grilled and fresh on top of house made fettuccine and fresh pesto sauce.   If you are in the mood to experience what San Francisco used to be like try these guys, you will not be disappointed !
author: BGinLove B.

description:
My rating is actually 2.5, but bumped it
Up to 3 stars. This place was featured on a PBS show and it looked promising. The service was decent and somewhat acceptable considering how busy this place was. I ordered the Caesar salad with grilled calamari and had high expectations. I was let down. The portion of calamari was very meager. The quality of the romaine and the dressing was on par. Had the calamari avoided being charred. Husband had the shrimp sandwich (not the menu name) and it consisted of a weird sweet bun and small Bay shrimp. The only thing memorable were the olives and bread they offer prior to the meal. It was quite the trek to this place and parking was not a breeze. The streets are small and people drive recklessly so be forewarned. We were so disappointed as we had high expectation as they were featured on Bay Area, Check Please. Perhaps it was an off day. Can't say I'd give it another try.
author: Lynn E.

description: Wanted to try something new for lunch and was at my parents place visiting, so yelped and found this place.  Rating and pictures looked fabulous so gave it a try.  Food was amazing; ordered the steamers (clams in garlic wine and lemon), vongole (fresh fettuccine with clams, garlic, wine, butter, small hint of creme), and a small clam chowder pot pie (clam chowder baked in a pot pie shell).  The clams were of a good size and fresh as heck.  The steamers dish, which is enough for 2-4 depending on how much other things you order, had an amazing garlic wine lemony broth - sweetness of the clams with refreshing lemon juice.  The vongole' s pasta noodles were freshly made and had good texture, and the clam chowder was tasty BUT wish they'd toast the pot pie shell a bit more.  Info said that the place was good for kids, but probably 2-3 year olds and up, since space was a bit cramped.  Overall a good solid 4!!!
author: Raymond F.

description: Just found this recently in Cortlandia and love love love it. Seafood pot pie was excellent, raw oysters impeccable. Sat at the counter and happy I did, the tables seemed like they could be a bit close together.
author: Mark P.

description:
Red Hill Station was a straight-up bad lunch.  We were a table of 4 people: two of us ordered the "Oyster Pot Pie" ($20); one ordered the fish tacos; the other ordered the "Lemon Thyme Cod", and asked for it to be made gluten-free.

The worst crime:  the "oyster" pot pies... mine contained 1/2 of one oyster (cut into two teeny pieces); the other diner's contained one single full oyster (cut into 2 pieces).  They arrive looking wonderful, with crispy browned puff pastry, but when you cut open the pastry, you find a thin, watery cream-based soup (homemade at least) with chiffonaded leeks and cubed potatoes -- and VIRTUALLY NO OYSTERS!  I'm not sure why they couldn't have thickened the mixture with a simple roux, and I'm absolutely mystified as to why an "oyster pot pie" for $20 didn't contain at least 3 or 4 oysters!

The second issue:  the "lemon thyme" cod...when we asked our server if the dish could be made gluten free, he said that they would leave off the bread crumb coating on the fish.  I said, "But you'll include the lemon and the thyme?", to which he said "yes".  When the dish arrived, it was a piece of plain UNSALTED/UNPEPPERED boiled cod with no lemon or thyme.  My companion had to ask for salt and pepper, because unseasoned fish is unpalatable.  It is beyond me why they couldn't have seared the fish with a little thyme, S&P, and lemon rind; gluten free should not have to be "flavor free"!

The fourth diner had the fish tacos, and said that they were "good" but unremarkable.

Come on, Red Hill Station -- surely you could do better than that!!!
author: N W.

description:
The food was very good--except the burnt funnel cake.  But the services was horrific.  One person's dinner came out with the appetizer. They forgot one person's soup.  

They were totally disorganized and inattentive.  There were plenty of servers and staff but they were not paying attention to their jobs or didn't know what their jobs were.  We weren't in a hurry and had a good time but for the price I wouldn't come back due to the atrocious service.  It was like how I remember the crappy pizza joint staffed with inexperienced high school and college students back when I was an adolescent.  No one was in charge and it had an air of chaos and unprofessionalism. It's a shame, really.
author: Jules a.

description: Very nice neighborhood place. There is a variety of seafood and a few other non-fish choices. I liked my philly cheese steak.
author: Irma P.

description:
The pesto pasta with prawns is the best on the menu! 

Also try the carbonara dish. Fresh and creamy. 

I'd pass on the chowder sampler...looked good but it was a bit salty.
author: Cindy N.

description:
Hands down deserving of a 5/5 star review rating. I came here on a Sunday night and was seated immediately. Our waiter Luke was down to earth and super helpful with helping us decide what to order. We were served complimentary olives (highly addictive - marinated and boiled  daily), fresh bread and balsamic etc. 

The menu had a ton of great options but we opted for the pesto almond pasta with shrimp and the clam chowder pot pie - BOTH extremely delicious. 

Highly recommend this spot for a date night! 

Cheers!
author: Sederic G.

description: If you like oysters, go here. Happy hour 5-7, $1.50 each. They bring warm olives and bread. They have 4 varieties tonight, 2 local, 1 Canadian, 1 New Zealand.  Amazing!!!
author: Dusty B.

description:
Wow. You turn up on a Sunday night over an hour before they're scheduled to close and they harass to to order your dinner before you've even picked up the menu, because it's slow and they want to leave.

Welcome to Red Hill Station. Enjoy your dinner.

And THEN AS I LEFT,

A server started mouthing off.  His name was Tony. He had nothing to do with my dinner what so ever.

And he wouldn't back down. It felt very ugly and I left. Even one of the staff had to physically restrain him. I'm not making this up.

I'm no victim here, but I don't understand how this guy felt so entitled to verbally abuse me considering him and I had had no actual dialogue prior to that. 

To their credit, they saw some of the ugliness and were embarrassed, and offered to refund my dinner. 

That's why they get 2 stars.

Tony yelled something about my having a bad day, but nothing was further from the truth. I took myself out to dinner to celebrate a significant event today.
author: JH M.

description:
Solid seafood place in bernal. Perfect for a weekend brunch with a glass of rose and the NYT, preferable the wedding section. Did I say that out loud? Delicious oyster platter, cioppino, puff pastry pot pie. How can you go wrong with puff pastry. Get the mini if you just want a taste. Cutest thing ever. 

We did ask if they had uni, which would have totally made our day, and made sense since it's a seafood place. Puzzlingly, NO UNI. We may be a little obsessed with Uni (see other reviews) but we think this is an area where maybe the management could consider augmenting the menu =).
author: Aman H.

description: Ordered the halibut and oysters. They oysters are fresh and halibut is tasty. I felt hungry after few hours and It would be great if the halibut is little bit larger.
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
Dinner review. 

Fried night smelt - 3/5
Calamari salad - 4/5
Chowder pot pie - 3/5
Pork pot pie - 4/5
Beef pot pie - 4/5
Pot de creme - 2/5
Mushroom creme brulee - 4/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Food was delicious and fresh, and seasonal. Servings are a good portion and not overly expensive. The bread before the meal served with extra virgin olive oil and balsamic vinegar we're amazing. I would also recommend the pot pies the come regular size or mini I got the clam chowder pot pie and it was better then what I have tried at fisherman wharf . It is a very small restaurant maybe 8 tables I recommend getting a reservation if you plan on going at night
author: Anthony U.

description:
The clam chowder pot pie was nice and piping hot albeit a bit on the watery side. For the price, I'd say it is quite a steep $19 before tax and tip. A small side salad came with it but it was undressed and comprised of a just small handful of leafy greens. There was free bread and olives but I had to grab a burger elsewhere to finally feel full. Perhaps serve a clam chowder bowl pot pie and charge half the price or offer a bigger portion of salad with more than just greens? 

My friend got the trio of pot pie and I felt a little ripped off for her. Get the whole rather than 3 little pies. Needless to say, my friend was mighty hungry after we left and headed to find more food. 

I may come back for happy hour to give this place another chance. I wanted to love this place and I'm glad I finally had a chance to check it out.
author: W A.

description: 7 years in SF and one of the best meals I've ever had! Highly recommend. Get the halibut!
author: Ryan J.

description: First time here, we enjoyed the place.  Nice menu options.  Good prices.  Good value for what you get.  We shared the shrimp stuff avocado.  It was very good.  Then shared a mini oyster pot pie, again very tasty.  Sort of an oyster stew with pastry.  I had the steam clams.  I see mussels on the menu in SF all the time, but rarely steamed clams.  They were very tasty, if perhaps cooked a minute too long.  Broth was great.  They have very good bread here to dunk in the broth.  A small, but reasonably priced wine list.  We'll be back.
author: David F.

description: Great stop on our trip to SanFran. A great neighborhood restaurant with high quality food and excellent staff. If you like oysters on the half shell there are several different varieties to try and they will provide you with a good description of the differences. The Oyster Shooters are unique and AMAZING, a must-try. The Hanger Steak was sust succulent and cooked to perfection. Even the bread is to die for. There was a slight wait to be seated (which is a favorable sign to us) and the couple minutes were well worth it. Great selection of wines. Red Hill is off the beaten tourist routes but easy to get to by Uber. It was off the charts as far as we were concerned, a true culinary gem.
author: Dan K.

description: Great little neighborhood seafood spot. Seated quickly on a Thursday early happy hour. Oysters were great and only a buck fifty each. Cioppino for two was huge, and broth was delicious.  The only drawback was the bread.  It was good, but a little heavy for seafood. I think "wheaty" was the term I used, rather than sourdough or rustic Italian which I would expect in SF.  I will go back for sure.
author: Andy O.

description:
Very disappointed with our meal tonight. Server was great, nice guy, attentive and friendly. We started with the calamari salad that was good so we were excited for our main courses. The mussels and clams was all broth and not very tasty, only about 7 mussels and a few clams in a huge bowl and not cheap. The cod was good, but tiny served with mashed potatoes that were tasteless. There was no presence of a manager and noticed guests waiting at the door while sever/ hotess was looking at her phone. 
We tell our server and he felt badly and bought our dessert.
We won't be back, sad because we live close by.
author: Ana L.

description: Delicious! Highly recommend to anyone who loves seafood.  Loved the cold crab, oysters and the clams. We hit during happy hour on a Sunday and enjoyed half priced oysters and draft wine! Highly recommend to others--went with my mom but would be great in a small group. Funnel cake and chocolate creme were amazing!  Perfect ending for the meal.
author: Jessica J.

description:
This place stole my heart. Set in an intimate cozy setting, you feel like your in someone's kitchen. The food was so fresh I could swear I saw it glimmer.
All that said, the staff... I've never felt more welcome or taken care of. The servers Julianna and Justin felt like old friends who want to feed you and listen to your stories. If I lived here, I would be a regular for sure. Thank you Red Mill Station, you made my weekend!
author: Ameana D.

description: We had a wonderful meal! The pot de créeme will knock your socks off! Jack the waiter was pretty cool.
author: Jay G.

description:
It was really busy and the service was super slow when I went on a Thursday around 7pm. We didn't get served for almost an hour it felt like. At least they eventually gave us bread. 

Otherwise, the food was good. We had the mixed dozen oysters on a half shell and those were delicious. The varieties and freshness of the oysters was so amazing. The Alaskan cod was alright, not too amazing. The andouille sausage linguini was so good though! Definitely get be linguines. We also had the mussels and clams in the wine broth. Seafood was super fresh! 

Although the service wasn't too great that day, I can forgive because the food quality is good for the higher price you pay.
author: Kelly N.

description: Tried this place for the first time and it didn't disappoint one bit! Went in on a Sunday evening without a reservation and had to wait about 20 minutes. Everyone coming in had a rezzie, so I think that's the way to go in this tiny restaurant. Service was great and food was too. The menu on the website had more options than the actual menu, so note that if you look online, it's just a sample menu. This is a wonderful neighborhood gem and I'm so glad we stumbled on it!
author: R S.

description:
I came with my mom and siblings. The service was definitely nice. If I could give service a 5 star, I would, but overall I'll have to give a 3 because the food wasn't that great. We ordered a dozen oysters and received 6 oysters that were decently sized and 6 tiny oysters the size of a penny! Some were nasty tasting.. We also ordered 6 oyster shooters that were pretty decent. I asked for no cilantro and the server was very nice about it. We also ordered the clam chowder pot pie and loved it, the linguine with clams was sooo salty (and I'm thankful for the servers for refilling water constantly) and the noodles were hard and chewy, and the linguine pasta almond pesto was meh. 

Would I recommend? No.
Would I come for the service? Yes. 
Would I come again for the food? No.
author: Beverly L.

description: The oysters are incredibly fresh and clam chowder pot pie is amazing!!! Definitely recommend for happy hour 3-6 PM!
author: Kora L.

description: It seems like a nice and cozy place, but unfortunately both me and my friend got food poisoning after eating here. We shared oysters and then main dishes were different, so oysters are the suspect. Hugely disappointed.
author: Onur S.

description:
Bumped into this whole in the wall place in Bernal Heights. Everything was amazing about it, the decor, the service and the food. I wish I could have tried everything on the menu. Reasonably priced for a seafood place and the food was delicious. Definitely will come back again!

I highly recommend the grilled calamari salad, the clam chowder pot pie, the cioppino, and the clam and sausage linguine dish.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
We love this place! We went this past Saturday for the 3rd time and again it was delicious.  This time we brought my parents and they also raved about it. We got the mussels, clam pot pie, carbonara pasta and the burger......yummm!

The service is always on par and quality of the food is wonderful.  

I cannot wait to come back...again!
author: Maryn R.

description:
The food is great.  What is not so great is the service and the uncomfortable seats.  The staff could be warmer and a little more sociable.  This is an intimate  neighborhood restaurant, after all.

It would be great if they changed the chairs.  It takes away from the dining experience when one is uncomfortable.
author: Emilia G.

description:
Grilled calamari caesar salad 5/5
I could eat so many of these... but sadly they are $19 :( 

No matter... it's worth every penny, for succulent calamari on a bed of crisp romaine spears. The caesar flavor is mild. It's rich and hearty because of the small colorful cuts of calamari grilled with some amazing buttery rub, and the dressing adds a refreshing, lemony kick!

This place is a gem. Great oysters, food, wine, beers on tap, and a quaint, home-y fine-dining feel.

I will be back for Kusshis, PEIs, and any other Canadian oysters I can get my hands on.
author: Fiona Y.

description: This place never disappoints. I can say never because I live two blocks away. They have a great happy hour of oysters and wine. Their greens are uniquely flavorful (not the standard store bought greens). The fish is fresh and cooked to perfection. The bread is fresh baked. The olives are warm and delightful. You literally can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Whitney S.

description: Wow. This place really rocks. Blown away by the Red Hill Special. Left me dreaming of Balthazar in NYC but I'm here in SF in my own neighborhood!  I hear the happy hour is amazing- next my list of things to try. Service excellent, wine excellent. Such a nice environment too. My new favorite in the hood.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Red Hill Station has become one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I've been here twice so far and can't wait to go back!

The restaurant itself is pretty small but cozy. There are tables in the front and bar seating along the open kitchen. I believe there are also some tables in the back of the restaurant for private parties.

For appetizers, I've tried the Red Trout Tartare and the Bay Shrimp Stuffed Artichoke. The tartare was more like a ceviche, which wasn't big deal. The taste was simple, but still good and refreshing. It was great that they were pretty generous with amount of fish they put in. The bay shrimp appetizer on the other hand, was really small for $16. It was a refreshing dish also, but it wasn't anything special.

For entrees, I've tried the Monterey Calamari Grilled Salad, Toasted Almond Pesto Linguini with Gulf Prawns, and Vongole Manilla Clams Linguini. I've gotten the calamari salad during both visits, because it's that good. The salad itself was very refreshing with ingredients of beets and grapefruit. The calamari was seasoned and grilled to perfection. The pesto pasta was the best I've ever had! Usually pesto pastas lack flavor, but this one was excellent. There was a great amount of sauce and the prawns were also seasoned and cooked perfectly. The clam pasta was my favorite out of everything! The linguini was cooked al dente and the sauce was nothing short of amazing. They were generous with the clams, and everything tasted really fresh.

For dessert, we got the Candy Cap Creme Brulee. It was small, but really good. It is a little sweeter than the usual creme brulee, but we didn't mind. If you're looking for something sweet at the end of the meal, that's the option to go with.

Service was great both times I've come. They checked up on us during each dish to make sure we're enjoying everything.

Overall, this is just an all around great restaurant! You won't be disappointed in anything you order. If I could give this place more than 5 stars, I would! I will be recommending this place to every seafood lover I know.
author: Derek T.

description: Can't write enough goods things about it. Every crumb they make is so delicious and the staff couldn't be nicer. Don't accept the free bread! It's too good and appetite killer. The Caesar salad is divine. The tuna melt is heavenly. The almond pesto so good. And I'm still full from getting the cippino last year.
author: Catherine C.

description: HORRIBLE! The worst cioppino I've ever been served. We shared the "double" portion. $72 for about 10 mussels, about 10 clams (some unopened), a piece of fish and 4 shrimp, with a ton of onions filling the bowl. NO CRAB!!!!!!!!!!! Menu promised crab but NONE in the bowl. Easily the worst and most overpriced dish I've been served in years. The salad with calamari was good, wish that was all we ordered. Salad w/ calamari, above mentioned cioppino, one glass of wine and one beer. $150 out the door. ONE HUNDRED AND FIFTY DOLLARS! Easily the most disappointing meal I've ever had in San Francisco (I've lived here 20 years). Service was poor, never refilled water and never came back to see how we were doing. I feel completely ripped off and utterly disappointed. AVOID!! NEVER AGAIN!!!!
author: mark f.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner and was pleasantly surprised. This is a small restaurant that serves amazing pot pies. We ordered the seafood tower, clam chowder pot pie and oyster pot pie. The seafood tower is really fresh and the pot pies are comforting when eating it on a cold night. I like the location of this restaurant because it's not really in the city. It feels like it's nestled in a quiet neighborhood.
author: Jeffery S.

description:
A good atmosphere restaurant. Phenomenal service. Prompt seating. Greeted by the server as soon as I walked in, they seem to know who I was and led me to the table right away. I was 10 minutes early for my 8:15 reservation too. Nice to see they saved a table knowing you would show up. Some restaurants may tell you that they are running late even though you had a reservation which is obviously annoying. So this was just an incredibly smooth start.

And that's not all. We found a parking space right by the restaurant. This never happens in North Beach, SoMa, Nob Hill, Russian Hill, Marina, the Mission or Richmond. Just can't happen. Imagine that. Saturday evening, prime dining time, and viola, stars aligned and there we were.

The restaurant is quaint, stylish, cute and inviting. I liked that. Every restaurant so far in Bernal just felt that way. It's a very welcoming sight. We need more of that. 

Since I eat out practically ever night, and some weekends and lunches too, it's important to find those restaurants that created a right ambience that makes you want to come back to. Like Blue Plate or Front Porch. I already like this restaurant before setting my foot in.

The white pots hanging by the kitchen were neat. Turned out they serve their famous fish stew in. Friendly staff come by very quickly to chat with us. Asked what was popular and she recommended a few things. 

It's important to pause here and note my companion choice of the night. N is French. As French as one can get without getting on my nerves. Our unique sense of humor come out together when we are together. Some people may think we are juvenile but when it comes to dining partners, N is as good as it gets. He knows his wine. He knows what goes with what. He is also disciplined like a French to not ever over order. I prefer him ordering because like a typical Chinese (well, I'm mostly Chinese as I recently learned on 23andme and bunch of other stuff), my eyes are bigger than my stomach and if it was left to me, the entire menu would be ordered. So I let him.

For that evening, he chose the monterey squid salad, which was supposed to be good. And mussels. The lady said the magic word of moules. What kind of French does not like moules? The kind that is NOT French of course. Wine pairing of the night was a light red N selected. I asked for coffee as I had started the day early with yoga, cycling, and attending an afternoon party. Surprisingly, the coffee was delicious. It's hard to imagine a restaurant serves coffee well when their main thing is seafood, but for reasons unclear, this was one cup of exceptional coffee. 

Staff came with green olive in sort of fish flavored sauce as a complimentary dipping sauce. Then the sourdough bread. Then the squid salad, tender and fresh local squid served on a bed of organic greens and grilled asparagus tip. 

Mussel dish is not just filled with mussels but with sausage, served in a huge pot filled with steamy spicy and creamy broth, but not so creamy that you don't want to drink it. Nothing like drinking warm creamy broth on a windy evening makes one want to sing happy notes after, which, coincidently, was where we were headed after: a private saloon open mic party nearby.

The meal was thoroughly satisfying. For two people, one salad and one entree to share was more than enough, especially if you couple it with a glass of wine or two. 

The fish stew looked exceptional actually besides what we ordered. The service was fantastic, easy parking, and the on time seating made it even more appealing.

A great restaurant to come and hang out with your favorite bud.
author: Victoria E.

description: Always fresh, delicious food, friendly, non-pretentious service.  My favorite neighborhood place. Very few places have good cioppino and they make one delicious one - every time! They also very accommodating if we sometimes  show up without reservations. Highly recommend it.
author: Ausra S.

description: Oysters, house made pasta and the bread all very delicious. Biggest problem is the portions are quite small compared to what you pay.
author: Maleah A.

description: All I can say they are truly not allergy friendly. My husband had a special ate quickly since everything I am allergic to even the almond bread. He felt super bad. I asked for a lemonade and they gave me a soda.
author: Colleen D.

description: Yum! My husband and I went there last Friday and had everything. This place is great, definitely a great neighborhood find. Clam chowder pot pie and  a glass of rose, perfect!
author: Maria C.

description:
The space is very cute and it's in a nice Bernal Heights neighborhood. It was not super busy on a Tuesday. Igor when we showed up. Service was slow but pleasant. 

Our wine was served lukewarm and that was the only Sauvignon blanc that they had. Other than that everything was tasty. We loved their seafood soup which was delightful and really hearty and comforting. We also did their fried fish which was lovely and fresh. 

I would recommend going there and ordering some of their pot pies as well.
author: Rohan D.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. Cute decor (although...see picture) and interesting menu. 

I got the mussels and my companion ordered the burger. 15 bucks and it comes with fries. My companion said the burger was meh.
My advice to the chef. Go down the street to Vega. Order the mussels. That is what mussels should taste like. Your broth is not quite  like gourmet hot dog water but it's too close for me. I wanted to like you but you make it difficult. Also, please advise your staff not to sit next to a couple who may be on a date and then proceed to make 25 phone calls confirming reservations.
author: Carla G.

description:
Some things are just too good to be true:

(1) A hot guy with brains and personality.
(2) A hot girl with brains and personality. 
(3) A Bernal Heights restaurant with an overall 4.5 star rating: Red Hill Station.

Why?

It's all subjective. 

Mr. NSS always tells me, "Do you think Channing Tatum and Megan Fox are casted for their awesome, Oscar worthy acting ability?" I don't know what he's talking about...Tatum's "performance" in Magic Mike was Oscar worthy in my book. *Cue in Ginuwine's Pony*

With the exception of Ichi, I've never been impressed with any of the restaurants in Bernal Heights which is a shame since I live nearby. I bookmarked Red Hill Station when they first opened in June 2014 but wanted to see how the reviews were before paying a visit. They maintained quite stellar ratings and it was close by to where both my gf and I live so we thought, now was the time to give them a shot. 

Sorry but after dining there, I don't understand the hype over Red Hill Station. It's overrated; the food is mediocre at best and the service is disorganized.

After our waitress recommended the Carbonara ($16.95), my gf and I split that as a starter: http://bit.ly/1zmDAaI. The pasta was perfectly al-dente and the carbonara was rich and creamy. I liked the addition of breadcrumbs for a nice textural contrast. Usually carbonara is made with diced bacon or pancetta but oddly, the bacon here was in strips, making it difficult to eat. 

Here's where things went downhill... 

Knowing that the owners are Anchor Oyster Bar alums, I was most excited for the Cioppino which was available in half and whole orders. The waitress said that, a "whole" order comes with a whole crab while a "half" order comes with half a crab. We ordered a whole to share as our main ($35.95): http://bit.ly/1BcgqWF. We were baffled when a huge platter was set on our small table with a bunch of mussels and two dinky pieces of crab. My gf has a fish allergy so they kindly left out the cod.

We alerted one of the staff who turned out to be the owner. We thought maybe they made a mistake in the kitchen and told her we ordered a "whole". She apologized for our server's miscommunication and said, "That's how the cioppino is served here...without crab legs." My gf and I sat there really confused because I was 100% certain that I had seen crab legs and claws served in the cioppino pics posted on their Yelp page. I then asked, "So the restaurant charges for a 'whole' crab but only give customers two pieces?" She looked as confused was we were and offered to take it off our bill which was a nice gesture. She added that if we wanted a whole crab, then we could have ordered the Crab with white wine sauce. We would have but that wasn't on the menu we were given: http://bit.ly/13JL52W. 

Aside from the missing crab pieces, the cioppino was sorely disappointing and not even in the same league as Anchor Oyster Bar. The mussels were meaty and tender but the broth/sauce was nothing more than canned tomatoes with herbs throw in as garnish. It was devoid of any flavor whatsoever.
