This was NOT a cioppino but rather a mussel tomato stew garnished with crab that ended having one tablespoon worth of meat. 

Service was disorganized and confusing. We were seated by a male staff member who we thought was our waiter. When other tables who came after us started ordering (we were first to arrive), a female server came over to us and said, "Oh you guys never ordered?" =/ Nope. She was really nice though. We were there for dinner but the menus said, "lunch". My gf and I then were given dessert menus...from different seasons. The cioppino was still on the bill and we had to alert the owner to take it off. 

Previously Tinderbox Restaurant that shuttered in 2008, I'm not a fan of current cramped and loud space. The tables are small and too close for comfort with (guy next to us almost accidentally knocked over our plates). Additionally, the serving platters are too clunky and it was annoying having to play table Tetris. Not the best place for an intimate date because of the poor acoustics.

Mediocre dinner and lackluster service aside, with the kind gesture to comp the cioppino dish, I was going to give Red Hill Station 3 stars. That's until, I went home and saw the following which confirmed my initial thought and contradicted what the owner had told us:

http://bit.ly/1AS3A1O

Admittedly, I may have beer goggles on half the time but that is crab claws and crab legs no?!?

Not cool, Red Hill Station.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
We had our latest dinner club here and it was a greta pick.  Red Hill Station is a small spot but they had a little somewhat private room above the main dining area.  It was perfect for our group as we had 8 people.  Their beer and wine selections were good and we definitely took advantage of them.

We started with the tartare (really good), calamari salad (decent), fries, and oysters.  Everything was really good and were good portion sizes.  For my main meal I went with the recommended Carbonara and it was excellent.  It was a lot but I devoured the whole thing.

For dessert we shared the creme brulee and pot de creme.  Both were good but not a must have.

Great intimate spot in Bernal with great food.
author: Blake B.

description:
Overall, Red Hill is an above average, neighborhood restaurant. I appreciated the on time seating, friendly service, and fresh food. I loved the private table we had reserved at the back of the restaurant - it was a cozy booth with a window to the kitchen. I would not encourage walk ins because the restaurant is small and pretty popular.

The key to a good experience at Red Hill is ordering the right dishes - I loved my first experience but thought the second visit was average. You MUST order the mushroom creme brûlée if it's still on the menu! I was unimpressed by their supposedly famous pot pies (too heavy and salty) and ceviche, and would discourage you from the garlic cod. I would come back to try their the mussels, linguini vongole, or Caesar salads. 

* Complimentary bread and olives: Huge meaty green olives and bread served with olive oil and balsamic. I thought it was a nice way to start but the bread could be fresher. 
* Scallop Ceviche - 2.5 stars: This was one small, but beautifully presented, overly salty scallop.
* Tuna tartare - 3.5 stars: The tuna tartare was much better than the ceviche, it was good but standard.
* Sampler of Pot Pies - 3 stars: Clam chowder (standard), bolognese (too salty - least favorite), and pork shoulder (tasted like Moroccan lamb seasoning). Overall it's a cool and unique idea but I wasn't a fan. If I had to pick, I would order the pork shoulder.
* Garlic Cod - 2.5 stars: Overcooked and dry, not a fan of the sauce. 
* Linguini Carbonara - 2.5 stars: would return for other pastas but the carbonara is way too rich and reminded me of the Lean Cuisine carbonara sauce. Pasta not made in house. 
* Funnel cake - 3.5 stars: good, but standard. 
* Lacey strawberry - 3.5 stars: good, kind of light. 
* Mushroom Creme Brûlée - 5 stars: Surprising favorite with a strong mushroom flavor only when you first taste it. Weird but good!
author: Jess C.

description: We came in here a couple of weeks ago for the the first time. Although parking is not the easiest in the area it was well worth hunting for a spot!  The food was delicious all around from appetizers to fish!  Very fresh and well prepared entrees.  The wine list was small but well chosen. Overall the service was excellent and attentive.   We had one issue with either an order did not get put in or the kitchen missed it, but our server was very apologetic and comped the dish because it arrived so late.  I think so many of us  get so demanding and expect perfect service all the time, but we all make mistakes (don't we), but  I judge how you handle them in the end.   We will be back for sure.
author: C W.

description:
The boy and I decided to go here for our belated Valentine's Day dinner and he really wanted to get ciopinno. It is a very small restaurant and when we arrived it was full so we left our cell number and they said it would probably be around 30 minutes and they would text us when a table was ready so we found a nearby bar and waited with a drink.  After about 35 minutes, we walked back even though we hadn't heard anything.  The host came out and apologized for the wait and offered me a blanket and gave us a drink menu.  He brought me a glass of wine and the blanket since there is no seating area to wait inside.  He continued to check on us (so nice!) and eventually we got a table looking into the kitchen which was a great view.  

He got the ciopinno and I got fettucini with andoiulle sausage and clams.  For our wait, the host gave us two oyster shooters on the house.  The food was so fresh, well seasoned and tasted amazing.  Our waitress was very nice and attentive.  The entire experience was great and we would definitely return.
author: Kristin P.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city. Food has the perfect amount of seasoning and is delicious. Well worth the trip into Bernal!
author: Dee K.

description: Perfect meal, from the service to all of the dishes. Great seafood options with a lot of depth of flavor.
author: Avi D.

description: We've been to Red Hill Station a number of times and it's always wonderful. The seafood is unbelievably fresh and pristine -- and delicious! -- and the atmosphere and service are lovely. My only wish is that it wasn't so loud in there. Maybe some fabric on the walls or ceiling to absorb some of the conversational din? I would eat there every week if I could!
author: Caroline P.

description:
Took my husband's family (7 of us) to this restaurant with good expectations based on the yelp reviews. It was his birthday lunch and I wanted to show his family visiting from southern CA an enjoyable time. They were excited about eating some great sf cioppino based on their delicious past experiences. I dine out with friends and family for the combination of good ambiance, good food, and good service, so here is my, and I speak for our family, review of our experience.

Food: 
Linguine with clams ($24)- so salty that our grandma had to pour water over it. Use more water and lemon when working with clams... it's naturally really salty. 

Salad with octopus ($22) - good dressing. Octopus was salty too... :( 

Hangar steak ($32) probably the best thing we had. There were 5 thin slices of steak and 2 Brussels sprouts but they were perfectly cooked.

Cioppino ($70) - cold, took 1.5 hours, and it was not up to par with anchor oyster bar. If you know it will take a long time for cioppino, set upfront expectations and maybe show some sincere care for the people who are staring quietly at the kitchen window anticipating the hot cioppino to come out. Maybe come by and say "sorry for the wait" and it will take x more minutes... even if it's and estimate.

Service: I have lived in the Bay Area for 5 years, and I never felt so much cold shouldering and discrimination from an sf restaurant. I hate speculating this as the case but I felt like we didn't even get one warm thank you or sincere "how is everything." I asked politely "do you know how much longer the cioppino will take" and I would get a snarky "we have a lot of people today so yeah..." I realized how much attitude really impacts diners' experiences at that moment because that whole meal became a huge waste of time and money. 

We we the only Asian family in the establishment... but I'm not going to assume racial prejudice. We felt it based on how we were treated compared to every other table, so I'll leave it at that.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: This a new top-5 place to eat in the city for me. Incredible food, fast service, reasonable prices. 10/10 will return
author: Spencer K.

description:
3.5 stars. 

The first time (2016) we came here for lunch I loved it and the second time (2018) it was so so. 

First time: fresh seafood. The fried smelt was very fresh and balanced, without extra grease and fishi-ness that often come with fried fish. and the calamari was magnificent - just the right texture, quite a platter with other complementary greens, etc. 

I would not order the cioppino, a bit too sweet and thick for my taste, even though the ingredients are quite fresh. there are better ones in the city elsewhere.  the portions are quite large (if you do decide to go with cioppino, the half portion is enough to share.

Cute casual and neighborhood place - worth checking out. The chef came from Anchor Oyster bar.

The second time (2018) when I returned for dinner, we ordered the salmon and a side of scallops. Both are decent (not stellar) but I got some allergic rash from the food - may want to be more careful of what you order here.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Seafood here is pretty darn fresh. Ordered the pacific oyster pot pie - astoundingly light and flaky that really dips well with the chowder. Also tried the cioppino - very tomato-ey. I really liked the shrimp, but unfortunately they ran out of clams, so substituted a bunch of mussels. The dungeness crab was good, but tasted a little over-steamed or something. The cod was kind of blah. It's pretty windy on the small first floor; if you're lucky, try sitting at the cozy second floor table, which has a view of the kitchen.
author: Gerald C.

description:
Pretty legit brunch, a bit pricey for dinner. With big open windows, this is a nice place to enjoy the Sunday morning sunshine in Bernal Heights! 

The brunch menu is pretty small, but there were quality options! I got the eggs en cocotte. Each thing on my plate was really yummy--candied bacon, egg dish, even the toast. The eggs got a little too cheesy for me after a while though, so it was nice to have the other things on the plate to balance it out. 

My boyfriend got the steak and egg sandwich, and the bites I had were so flavorful--the steak was cooked just right, the bread was really soft, and on both plates, the side salad was surprisingly tasty. I normally forget about salads, but this one had big chunks of fresh grapefruit and I ate the whole thing. 

Only complaint was that there was a bit of a wait. For the small bunch of people in there with us, our plate took about 25 mins to get out to us. But we were seated right away!
author: Amanda A.

description:
My husband scouted this place out on one of his many sources. Made reservations for our date night Saturday at 7, easy street parking. 
The place is small and cozy, and has a really nice esthetic comfort feeling when you sit down.
We were seating right away by the front door and we did love looking out the window watching the world go by. Though, their door tends to stay a tad open as people enter and being SF the draft coming in if your the person with their back to the door can be a bit annoying. Good thing my hubby has a long arm to reach behind him to continually close it.

We started with a meatball appetizer in a lovely tomato sauce, mmmmm so good and save your sauce to dip your bread in too good to waste a drop! 
Oh and they serve you to start with some of my favorite, Castelvetrano mixed with garlic and olive oil eat all of these!

My husband had a mussel and Porkbelly dish which he thoroughly enjoyed, I went for what I smelled the minute we opened the door and walked in: Fish and chips! It really was a toss up between that and the salmon which equally sounded fabulous. But I kept thinking of when I walked in and how delicious and enticing that fish and chips smelled..... done and done.
And I wasn't disappointed! Crispy and the fish perfect and moist inside, serve with these  crispy matchstick style fries. Really loved it, only thing that didn't do anything for me was their take on coleslaw, it just had an odd flavor. I did give it two tries, but just wasn't my cup of tea. 
We finished our feast off with Chocolate Pot o' creme. Oh so rich and silky smooth. Glad we shared.
Rolled ourselves back to the car.
author: Susan D.

description: This was our second time here and our experience is consistently wonderful food and service at this small Bernal Heights gem. Hanger Steak and Trout Almondine entrées were our selections on NYE despite availability of excellent  prix fixe menu options with wine pairings. Chocolate Pot du Crème topped with fresh whipped cream and cocoa dust is an awesome desert. Though their coffee options are very limited, the house brewed regular coffee is delicious.
author: Scott C.

description:
OMG. Came here once and I already can't wait to go back. 

Went here on a Friday around 6pm and got lucky since we didn't have to wait. The restaurant is pretty small. We ordered the Bay Shrimp Stuffed Artichoke which was refreshing but small. I would say it was nothing special and you can definitely skip that dish. Now, onto the dish that I have been dreaming about eating again, the Vongole Manilla Clams Linguini! The pasta and the sauce were cooked to perfection. After every bite, I just kept on saying "Omg this is so good". The Candy Cap Creme Brûlée was also amazing. Probably the best creme brûlée I've ever had. A little bit on the sweeter side, but I love my sweets. Service was great! The only problem I had was that the food did take a little long to come.
author: Crystal C.

description: Our meal was lovely and DELICIOUS! Thank you soooo much for taking such good of care of the 4 of us. We had a terrific time! We ordered the oyster shooter appetizer and I was very reluctant because I don't like oysters because of the texture but those shooters were AMAZING! We each got something different so everyone could try it . Everything was soooo flavorful. The restaurant was packed but I can imagine that it always is. Mike, our server, was terrific! He was such a sweetheart. He was busy, we could tell, but every time he came to our table he treated us like we were the only people he was serving that evening. We are definitely going back!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
In this city of casual bites and gourmet new American eats, it can be tough to navigate the waters of quality against a tide of shuddering mediocrity.

Make no mistake, Red Hill Station is part of that tide.

On a Saturday I arrived and was seated quickly and comfortably by the pleasant staff.  This turned out to be the best part of the meal.

I asked about the delicious sounding linguine dishes, probably lured in by their minimal ingredients (dreaming of actual authentic Italian pasta...) and fancy price tags. Sad to hear, not fresh pasta.

I ordered their eponymous burger, rare. 
In my optimism I ordered an oyster shooter also.

What arrived was more cheese than burger, and certainly not rare.

Now I don't discount a meal for a delicate cooking miss, i.e. Rare vs med rare. So that's not it. But if only you could have seen this slapdash ensemble.

Have you noticed the oyster shooter was missed?

And the misery of desiccated fries accompanying the main course. Sorry red hill, I do not love paying $20 on a burger paired with Heinz. 

With a minor nudge, the oyster was remembered and created. And by that time they even offered it gratis. So basically this place when barely busy can't make a single oyster.

In any case let's summarize.

- food is not delicious or fresh. i.e. no real chef

- clearly cuts all corners (poor burger, Heinz?)

- run by amateurs who give away oysters.



If I didn't have this hangover I wouldn't have finished even a bite. Time to get ice cream.
author: Michael S.

description:
went here cuz i saw it oh an episode of Check Please..  unfortunately didnt realize the episode was from 2015..  what a difference time makes.  you'd think it would get better but  surprise..  disappointment.

i went there for the fish and chips cuz the reviewers all raved about it, one saying the portion was large (3 pieces of cod)!!!  well, despite the $18 price tag for it, i ordered it, and when it came,  to my surprise, the portion that was huge was the chips (thin fries and not the large style country "chips" you'd think came with it)  and, lo and behold,  not 3 pieces of fish, just 2!!!  for $18 !!!!

well, since there was no turning back the clock i tried the fish (note, they were not large thickly cut pieces,  but rather thin and two pieces no longer than maybe 5 inches each.   i expected the firm resilient but moist texture of a good codfish, but this was not that..  it was on the softer side, giving me question,  cod??  can't be sure.  

guess i should be more careful next time and get an updated review before trying it out.
author: dee c.

description: Ugh. Been coming to RedHill the past few years every so often when craving solid seafood. WAS my fav restaurant back when they had true thin shoestring fries and Oregon bay shrimp... Unfortunately had one of the worst $22 vongole clam pasta dishes recently there. No flavor, all clams were over steamed/out of shell and rubbery, and the broth had been reduced to a gel like consistency that wasn't worth 2 bites. I think because I used to love this place so much I'm extra bummed... please don't lose your edge red hill!
author: Grace M.

description:
The hubby and I decided to try something different for our anniversary.  We had not planned anything.  We decided to try Red Hill Station.  

WAIT TIME:
There was about a 15-20 minute wait, which wasn't too bad.  The group of 3 that arrived right after us was told the wait would be 30 minutes...so it's very dependent on how many people decide to go on any given night.  The restaurant is small and pretty much full the entire time we were there.  I recommend reservations, especially if there are more than 2 people in your party.  

FOOD:
We started off sharing a glass of French white wine (can't remember the name) which was excellent.
Hanger steak with vegetables: both the steak and the vegetables were delicious.
Andouille sausage and clam pasta with garlic lemon sauce.  That was FANTASTIC!  It was very lemony.  Even my husband thought it was fantastic.  
We had the funnel cake with blueberries and strawberries and decaf coffee.  Funnel cake was not quite as crunchy on the outside as I like, but it was delicious and not too sweet.  The coffee was strong, just the way I like it.

AMBIANCE & NOISE:
casual and not too loud.

SERVICE:
Our waitress was pleasant and helpful in explaining the items on the menu that I was not familiar with.

I will DEFINITELY go back!
author: Jane T.

description:
I loved Red Hill Station.  And I definitely see what the buzz is about.

Everything we ordered was great.  Friendly and helpful staff. The place is small so the tables are close together which is a down side, but we went early, just as they opened, so we didn't have to wait or fight the crowd.  In fact, we had the whole place to ourselves so neither were we bothered by the closeness of the tables.

We had:

+FISH N CHIPS (5/5) - Best F+C I've had in recent memory.  Perfect batter, perfect fry, perfect texture of fish. Heaven.

+CALAMARI CAESAR (4/5) - Delicious.  We shared it.

+PESTO PRAWN - (4/5) - Nicely put together.  Loved the pesto.  So many restaurants overdo the salt, but this one was balanced just right!

This is a restaurant that I wish was in my neighborhood.  This would be a once-a-week stop for me.  Kudos to the chef.  Out of the way for us, but I will definitely go out of my way to get to Red Hill.
author: Darien R.

description: This was our first time at this fantastic neighborhood restaurant. The food was delicious (caesar salad with calamari, pasta with clams, perfectly cooked halibut,) great and affordable wines, amazing homemade bread and fantastic service. (Juliana is awesome!) The funnel cake topped with whipped cream and berries for dessert was unbelievably good. Can't wait to go back!
author: Joseph S.

description: Walked in for Sunday brunch/lunch. We had cioppino and pot pie (oyster/bacon/leek), and finished with candy cap mushroom crepe brûlée - all were exceptional.  Service was knowledgeable, friendly, and attentive.  First time - definitely not last!
author: Monique Y.

description: Almost everything was perfect. Amazing food and great service. What a gem. The clams, mussels, hamachi, bread, and olives were all superb. With some tasty beers to boot.
author: Steve S.

description: Best meal we had in San Fran. The calamari Cesar salad was so freaking good, I started tearing up. The fish and chips were great as well. And you start with some house made bread and olives. Such a great find. Plus you're in bernal heights so go climb up the hill, eat here, and finish with a cocktail down the road at Holy Water.
author: Kaitlyn C.

description:
I was exploring SF with my friends when this restaurant shows up on Yelp. 4 and a half stars, why not try it out? 
We got the Cabenera Linguine and I think the grilled hanger steak, forgot what it was called but it was the only steak dish on there. 
Cabenera Linguine - it was okay, kind of dry. I could tell if I wasn't sharing it with my friends I would've gotten sick of it quick.
Steak - Really good, but pricey. I do recommend getting this dish though. The meat was medium - medium rare, but it was super juicy and tender. It came with a bunch of different veggies and their special sauce I really enjoyed. PS: they don't have A1 sauce.
Service & ambience - This is a very small place, kind of hipster. Everyone is really nice, but the service is really slow.
Overall, 3 stars for good food but overpriced. Worth a try, but I wouldn't come back.
author: Yvon D.

description: Such a delightful place with beautiful delicious food. Great menu simple yet offering a diverse array of seafood specialties. They have burger dish and non seafood and kids menu. Quick and friendly service. We sat at the bar facing the kitchen! The best view in the restaurant for me and my husband. The kitchen team is so very young (19 and 20 yr old with such impressive culinary talents and expertise) so talented! So much fun watching them prepare all the delicious meals! We lucked out - Thursday night no reservations and got a seat right away - 630ish. We shared the hamachi salad it was like buttah mealtime in our mouths- fresh great size hamachi slices!!!! I ordered the linguine with andouille sausage and clams. The sauce was so delicious and the dish was cooked to absolute perfection! Husband ordered the skirt steak and prawns and he devoured it! Again cooked to absolute perfection!!! Highly recommend and this is definitely one of my favorites in the city!!!
author: June R.

description:
At the risk of sounding like a real estate listing, this quaint Bernal Heights eatery bears a resemblance to my childhood home; details as simple as moulding and a door frame sparked nostalgia for that time in my life. 

A few ingredients were noticeably missing from our plates -- a pinch of salt & a dash of creativity would've enlivened dinner. We ordered: 
-- a side of fries: enough thin, limp fries to feed six.
-- artichoke stuffed with bay shrimp: as our waitress promised, shrimp were not fishy tasting, very mild actually. I don't think any part of this appetizer was seasoned. 
-- halibut: this had a nice salty-sweet brown butter sauce. The fish itself was firm & mild, which obviously I like, but not a tastebud pleaser on its own. His steak dish had the exact same components as my fish one: potatoes, Brussel sprouts, red pepper, nothing to differentiate one dish from the other. 

From crudo-type appetizers to pastas, Red Hill Station highlights seafood in all areas of its concise menu. The neighborhoody atmosphere, the familiar interior & layout, friendly waitresses -- all elements that make me want to return...if only they'd wave their magic wand to bring their flavors to life.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I really wanted to like this place as my gf's hubby is a foodie, and their previous dinner here was great.  My gf couldn't say enough of the linguine. 

Four for lunch yesterday at 12:15pm.  One table of two already seated.

Our server was prompt to take our drink orders, then starters and lunch entrees.

I ordered a cup of coffee.  Served in a cute cup and saucer.

We each ordered two sweet water oysters from Hog Island.  Very fresh.  Served on an iced paella skillet.

I decided on the Alaskan true cod fish and chips.  In my mind I'm picturing steak type fries.  My entree comes and the cod is atop a huge basket of skinny brown colored wimpy fries.  Ugh.  Not at all to my liking.  The cod is very good.  Nice and crispy coated.

Improvement needed - service was very very slow.  We got the oysters in reasonable amount of time.  Then it was wait, wait, wait.  Maybe 15-20 minutes.  And I had to request a coffee refill.  

3.5 overall stars as service was very slow and my fries were inedible. 

As we left the restaurant was 80% capacity.

I'm reluctant to give it another try as I would need to cross town to come.  But one of my friend's monterey grilled squid salad looked so delish.  She cleaned her plate.

$30 p/p inc tax & tip.
author: Shirley N.

description:
OK so I won't be going there on a regular basis because it is on the pricey side.  That said there are a few places I don't mind splurging a little because the food is excellent.  Red Hill Station is one of them.  We made a reservation on a weekday eve so didn't have to wait.  The three of us had a great experience from start to finish (we decided to share everything): they gave us olives and bread to nibble on while we waited for our food.  The bread was warm and delicious and the olives were out of this world.  Then we had:

*Amazing calamari salad
*The best fish & chips in San Francisco
*Beautiful and delectable salmon in flaky pastry cone crust with vegetables, magical...

I hope you get a chance to try it.

Oh I almost forgot to mention the great service we had: our waitress was so sweet and efficient, we even got extra olives :)

Goodness
author: Monkey B.

description: What a wonderful restaurant. Delicious food and wine, great service, and a lovely location. Fresh baked bread straight out of the oven and warm olives were a nice touch. We'll be back!
author: Emma A.

description: This place is perfection. Vibe is on the quiet side, non pretentious. Oysters = well-shucked and delish. Albacore tartare = want to eat it forever. Linguine alla vongole = incredible flavors of lemon and sea, al dente, soooo goood. Service was a little slow, but with all this great food and company, who cares?
author: Sara B.

description:
I hate being lied to...especially when there's proof...

After having Red Hill Station bookmarked for several months, my girlfriend and I decided to give them a try.  I hear they can get busy so I made a reservation on Opentable.  

For an appetizer, we decided to split the carbonara ($16.95).  The waitress' recommendation was amazing!  The sauce was creamy and topped with bacon and breadcrumbs.  Splitting the dish is recommended.  The size was perfect as a starter and the sauce would've been too rich to eat as an entree.

For our entree, we were both interested in the cioppino.  Being that I'm allergic to fish, I had ask if they use a fish stock before we ordered it.  Our waitress went to the kitchen and came back to inform us that they use tomato sauce and chicken broth and they would be able to leave out the cod to accommodate my allergy.  We went with a whole order ($35.95) for the whole crab (opposed to $23.95 for half a crab).  

When the cioppino came, it was in a huge platter, but something was wrong.  There were two tiny pieces of crab.  My friend and I had blank stares on our faces wondering where the rest of it was.  We spoke to who we appeared to be the owner or manager who said that's how their cioppino is usually served.  She informed us that "whole" and "half" on the menu meant the size of the order, not the amount of crab.  We let her know that our waitress had told the other table that it meant a half or whole crab.  She was apologetic and mentioned she would take the cioppino off the bill which I thought was a nice gesture.  Seriously though, I would NOT pay $36 for what appeared to be half of a crab body chopped in half, mussels, and what tasted like canned tomato sauce...and what do they do with the rest of the crab?!  The dish is skimped on the seafood and consisted mostly of tomatoes.  Not worth ordering.

My girlfriend was convinced she saw crab legs.  When we got home, she texted me a picture of what she found on Yelp...cioppino with crab legs and all.  Please don't lie, especially when there's proof on the internet.  

WHAT TO KNOW:
*Menu changes especially desserts with seasonal fruit
*Tables are tiny.  If we were the first party dining, why would you seat the next group who walked in right next to us instead of spacing parties out!?
*They don't pay attention to their menus.  Not sure if they used the same menu for both lunch and dinner, but our menus said "lunch".  When we got dessert menus, one of us got a menu with pear desserts, the other with mixed berry desserts.  The pear menu was old...
*Metered street parking which was easy to find on a weeknight
author: Nicole S.

description: I'd suggest this place as a textbook example of a perfect Californian / San Franciscan neighborhood gem. Great fresh seafood, relaxing and non-stressful setting, great price. I love bringing out of towners here.
author: Ken H.

description: Lively little place with a good-humored staff & hefty portions.
author: Matt L.

description: Everything was great and we felt just like we were at home. Good was so fresh and delicious. My husband who hates going out loved this place, though he was disappointed they don't serve iced tea. Great neighborhood spot!
author: Liz F.

description: Best place for oysters and service in SF! Hit up the oyster happy hour. Staff are friendly and prompt. Service exceptional. Food quality , superb.
author: Shaun Monica A.

description:
Yum yum yum. Best meal we've had since we arrived in the States. I had a super rich but delicious linguine carbonara with just the right amount of chilli flakes and maple bacon (*drool*) and he had a fresh spring salad with grapefruit, fresh greens, peppers and the most delicious, fresh chargrilled calamari ever. Yummo. 

Added in a crisp glass of rose for $10 and a lovely 21st amendment beer for $5 and we had a perfect late night meal to welcome us to San Fran. Not cheap though - all up including gratuity was around $65
author: Gemma H.

description: Took my impossible to please father to this spot, and neither of us left disappointed. Well managed, good value, lots of attention to detail. The pot pie flight was a treat, and my trout and veggies were beautifully prepared. Deserving of its high rating here. Happy hour, 3-6 PM, gets you cheap oysters and drinks. Beware reviews from yelp accounts with internet photos and only one review.
author: Nick C.

description: I hesitate to give four stars, but I really can't put my finger on why I initially thought the place deserved three, except that the service seems a bit forced. The food definitely is four stars, and the ambiance is good for dining alone for lunch. I didn't wait long for my orders because I dined during a slow time.
author: Paulina F.

description: Outstanding (and somewhat unusual) food!!  I had a fish dinner, and crab and salad.  Great service, too.  I didn't give 5 stars simply because the place is kind of plain;  not elegant.  And for the $$$, I'd prefer some elegance.  Maybe I'm old-fashioned... but it was indeed very delicious.  Hats off to the chef!   :-)
author: Fred Z.

description: I love to eat. This place I could eat at daly. It was my first time and the cod was done perfectly. Great find, I will be back.
author: Mark G.

description: This place was amazing! Great food, coming back!! Wonderful service, great oysters. Fish cooked to perfection, let the waiters choose for you!
author: Diana X.

description:
This is a really cute neighborhood spot!  Get a table by the window and watch people of Bernal Heights go about their business...

The caesar salad with grilled calamari has got to be one of the very best things I've ever eaten...in fact, I ordered TWO!  I shared the first one with my family but the second was all for me.  We also had oysters on the half shell, clam chowder, mini pot pie, and carbonara.  Everything was cooked to perfection but what really stood out was the delicious light broth in the clam chowder...yes, I did say broth, not the thick heavy white creamy soup.  And I love the fact that they used a mixture of shellfish.  The pot pie was insanely yummy.  Now, I am not a fan of carbonara but we ordered it for my husband.  I really liked how they made it and would definitely order it (from Red Hill only) again...that says it all.  

Go eat there everyone...not to be missed!
author: Evelyn C.

description:
We discovered this location after seeing a review on Check Please! Bay Area. Both my wife and I had the mussels with chorizo broth which was absolutely awesome, and others nearby had various other seafood dishes that made my mouth water while we waited for ours. The staff were super friendly and attentive as well.

We would both recommend this place and plan to come back whenever we are in the neighborhood!
author: Erich N.

description:
Had a wonderful meal here with a friend. Other restaurants in the area were over an hour wait on Thursday evening but we were able to get in quickly. 

The bread service was delicious with olives and roasted garlic. 

We shared the tuna tartare but I really wish u could have had it to myself. 

We ordered the fish tacos because SF. they did not disappoint. The fish was meaty and cooked excellently. Well balanced flavors and very filling. 

We probably went overboard when we went for the special. A whole crab in warm buttery garlic broth. Fingerling potatoes and half an artichoke made this dish spectacular.  I wanted to have the broth to go. 

Service was lovely and friendly. I'll definitely be back.
author: Robert D.

description: I stopped by and had a Caesar Salad with Calamari and it was deliscious!  The calamari was grilled and served warm in a bed of romaine lettuce.  Dressing was excellent with crunchy bits sprinkled all over.  Great contrast of having warm calamari with cold salad.  Great portion.  Was worth coming here from the east bay.   I highly recommend this place if you are in the city looking for a local restaurant in the Bernal Heights area.  Mike was my server and he was excellent.  He checked in on me and filled my half full glass each every time he came by.  Friendly staff, excellent food and reasonably priced.  I met Amy and she was super nice as well.
author: Larry M.

description: My Sweetie and I just discovered Red Hill Station. Having just returned from a long trip outside the USA I was hankering for a delicious American meal, and RHS delivered. I had the delish fish tacos, house Pinot at happy hour, my sweetie had oysters which he praised and devoured in seconds. His main course was pasta with clams and we both loved it. Homemade bread was wow. The whole thing was a great new find which I know will be one of our Go-to eateries! PS ask for the green and red salsa with the tacos, it doesn't come with it, but it makes it!
author: Bridget K.

description: So good. Delicious halibut. Great service. Really enjoyed the oysters and wonderful white wine - like a sancere but something else recommended by our excellent server.
author: Seth B.

description: horrible service. Waiters are lazy and don't have exact time of when things will be done. Worst experience of my life. don't waste your time if they are busy. will not take care of you.
author: Mecedes G.

description: No waiting. The service is very friendly. Love their bread! Salad was very yummy. I didn't really care for my main entree not sure how to explain it. Funnel cake was also super good. Might not come back next time. But a great experience.
author: Jennie C.

description:
This is my second visit to this restaurant. 

And I am coming from Rockford, Illinois to eat there.

Whenever I have a friend or colleague come out to the Bay Area, I make sure to direct them to this restaurant. Taylor and Amy have gone to great lengths to make this restaurant a premiere place to eat.

I was never a fan of calamari unless it was deep fried. Taylor has added it to the Caesar Salad and it is fantastic. 

I also tonight had a staple of the restaurant - the fish and chips. So many fries and two huge pieces of cod. Both excellent. And make sure you eat the slaw because that isn't just colorful garnish. 

Dessert - the creme brule - was also phenomenal.

Make reservations well in advance. Do not pass this place up!
author: James O.

description:
Nice place in a new, one-block gourmet strip near Gen Park. Two-level effect with a nice stairway down the middle. Copper-sheathed tables (warmer than it sounds). Service is friendly and likes to chat when it's not too busy.

The flight of meat pies is as good as it sounds. They make to order, and the pies are wonderful. The oyster pie had a little too much tarragon, but just a little: do not omit the tarragon! The beef pie was, well, rich and full and wonderful. The clam chowder pie was, for being white clam chowder, really fantastic.

We ordered the calamari salad due to other reviewers, and they are right: it is great. Tender squid, fresh greens. Dessert is good, and it's easy to eat too much (i.e. all of it). Bread pudding neither soupy nor dry.
author: Richard H.

description: You must have the calamari salad. The best I've ever tasted.  Five plus stars. The other seafood was four stars.  Dessert three stars (bizarre funnel cake apple concoction). Service was excellent and very friendly!
author: David S.

description: Excellent food and seafood and appetizers. Good service. A very enjoyable dining experience, did not disappoint unusual for this fussy couple.
author: m j l.

description: Yeah, it's great and seafood focused.  Get the oysters (steamboat FTW), the calamari salad (not fried, but tender and delicious), or the "red meat trout" (which is salmon-like and delicious, especially when served seared with brown butter and pan-fried sage).
author: Aaron M.

description:
OMG, what a cute little charming place in Bernal Heights!  This two months old seafood-centric place is brought to you by two Anchor Oyster Bar alums.  Since I love all kinds of seafood, I am always on the lookout for new seafood restaurants.  So, on this Thursday night, I dragged Mr. J out to get a head start on the weekend.

Red Hill Station offers a small intimate menu because it changes daily.  Mr. J and I got 3 appetizers, 2 entrees and 1 dessert.  I can't believe I forgot to order the oysters.  D'oh!  I was sad because they ran out of the black cod.

Things we had:

--- Caesar with fresh seasonal Oregon Bay shrimp - The light and tangy made to order Caesar dressing was in perfect harmony with the romaine and shrimp.  I am not a big fan of these tiny Bay shrimp because they are normally 'fishy', but not these ones!

--- Fried local fresh anchovies with pesto di limone - Just one word, ah-mazing!  This got to be my favorite dish for the night since I am still raving about it!  They weren't kidding when they said the anchovies are lightly breaded.  The breading was so thin that you don't even notice yet still added that extra texture.  I dislike overly breaded things and this is not one of them.  The pesto and the white sauce goes swimmingly with the anchovies.

--- Wild Ft. Bragg King salmon tartare with chives and red onion, crostini, micro arugula - Another light and refreshing dish.  The cracked black pepper on the toasted crostini was a great touch.

--- Grilled fresh Monterey calamari with roasted white peach and black fig vinaigrette, summer roasted cherry tomato and vegetable salad - Wow, it was beautifully presented and perfectly grilled.  Yumm...

--- Torchino pasta with cove mussels, savory clams, corona beans, fresh garlic, white wine, oregano, parsley, Italian sausage, pangrattata - This was probably my least favorite dish for the night, it was a bit 'too busy'.  I think it would be a better dish if the pasta was more al dente and the beans were taken out.

--- Lace cookies and cream, organic blueberries, strawberries - We were so full already but we had to try dessert.  Thankfully, this dessert was very light and not too sweet to wrap our night up.

Everyone at the restaurant were so friendly and attentive.  Everything were reasonably priced and their portion sizes were very generous.  Couple little friendly suggestions though...  It would be nice if the windows can open up.  It can get a little stuffy in there.  Also, maybe get some black linen napkins as well.  I was wearing black and the white linen napkin shedded tons of lint on me.  Not a super big deal.  Mr. J and I will definitely be coming back for more!
author: Kay Y.

description: This place is amazing. Good food, good wine. The servers were extremely accommodating even though we weren't aware that they take reservations. We waited for over 20mins but they kept apologizing and provided us a table to sit with bread while we waited after we decided to have take out instead. Definitely recommend this place to anyone. Make sure you make a reservation!
author: Er Wynn K.

description: My wife talked me into going there. It was good and we knew what to order before we got there. Seafood salad and fish n chips. Why this combo? No reason. First, the salad - A blob of soggy greens surrounded by grilled seafood, which wasn't bad. But, for 20 big ones, can't my greens at least stand firm for the first few minutes instead of lying there in an overly absorbed in an olive oil lump? I guess not. The fish in chips were...well, at least the fish, was excellent. The chips? I believe they ran the fries thru the ocean before settling in the bowl. Man, talk about salty. I thought a slightly less dash or two would do. Over all, not bad, not great. The City is full of haunts just like this....
author: David W.

description:
First off we are super excited to have a seafood themed restaurant in Bernal. We went over for grand opening last night.

We were seated relatively promptly for our 8pm reservation. The place was packed and I'm glad we made a ressie before hand. We got some oysters to start us off. (Very fresh!) Couple glasses of wine and some beer. Ceasar salad with bay shrimp shared with the table (delicious!) And we all had the sea trout with browned butter, asparagus, carrots, fingerling potatoes, topped with some crunchy almond! *sooo good!*

Too bad we were so stuffed, otherwise we would have the dessert, mission pie with Mitchell ice cream. 

I'm excited about this new addition to our neighborhood. Can't wait for them to expand the menu and some happy hour offering!
author: Winnie A.

description: This review is overdue.  I've been to Red Hill Station four times now, and it does not fail.  Oysters fresh, amazing, briny; the shooters (and I'm not usually a loaded oyster eater hahaha) make the oysters even greater.  The cioppino is also spectacular--my friend and I shared a large and were more than satisfied.  Bernal is low-key, so parking isn't the hassle it can be other places.  I'm pretty burned out on the SF restaurant scene, but I can't say enough about this place--I'll keep coming back.
author: Kennau K.

description: Not good enough.  Not particularly comfortable, very noisy, extremely mediocre (is that an oxymoron?) food, lifeless service.  The lighting was broken and so were all the beer taps.  And expensive.  I came here once before and thought it was a sweet little scene.  Maybe the A-team had tonight off, but this was very disappointing and I won't be back.  Too bad, but there are much better options at these prices...
author: Sammy B.

description: Best seafood place in the city. everything was FRESH and delicious.   The clams, oysters, cod and halibut were ordered and I don't know how they do it but they must have  a fish whisperer chef to prepare it so well.
author: mary g.

description: this place is ALWAYS GREAT!!  the food, service and ambience are PERFECT.  We ordered the hanger steak (really was cooked perfectly and the sides were all tasty as well,  the almond pesto wit prawns was nicely creamy and a unique blend of tastes done so well  the beers on tap offer a fine selection, the deserts that we ordered were fantastic the chocolate pot de creme super yummy the candy cap mushroom desert was a  unique savory and not overly sweet desert.  All in all a really good local restaurant and away from all the tourist hang outs,  still a unique spot in San Francisco
author: Tim R.

description: Been going there on a regular basis, today I was waiting for a table for one and the waiter decided to give it to the straight couple who came after me.   Last time I will support this place.
author: Susanne D.

description:
This is a transcendent food experience. If you are looking for a place to quickly shove familiar food into your face do not come here. If you are looking to enjoy delicious food carefully crafted to be both artful and homey at the same time this is the place. 
Every time I have been here I have received excellent service, and been treated to food that is simultaneously surprising and comforting.  This is a difficult feat to pull off.
author: Diana S.

description: Yummy! This place fills up quickly. Our waiter was friendly and upbeat in spite of how crowded it got. The oysters he chose were great and my linguini delicious !! Excellent service and food and cool space
author: Cecilia D.

description: Red Hill Station is a hit! Neighborhood gem. We adored our meal in every way. First. Staff responsiveness & service are outstanding. They know their stuff & are really happy to have you. Each course was a dream version of the particular dish- the shrimp in avocado salad? Devine interpretation. The lamb chops? To die for. The chicken pot pie with filo dough crust that was crispy & chewy at the same time??? And went on forever??? With chicken & veggies in a light savory creamy chicken stock? Well, let's just say it was The Platonic ideal of 'Chicken Pot Pie'. When we thought 'things cannot get any better than this', we got our dessert of chocolate pots de creme. Mon Dieu! Over the top!! What a fantastic restaurant. Can't wait to go back when we're in Bernal again.
author: Lin B.

description:
This little secluded spot is awesome. Awesome! I got the pot pie sampler: one was clam chowder, the second was oysters, and the third was like a pork shoulder barbecue. It was essentially three of my favorite foods served inside of one of my other favorite foods. 

The crust was flakey and light, flavorful and fantastic. The fillers were inventive and tasty and just sooo good. 

The waitress was sweet and attentive as well, and it was one of those great restaurants where you don't have to shout to hear each other. I had a great time!!
author: Medina C.

description: Genuinely a fantastic place. Went here tonight for a friend's birthday and we had the private room in the back. The food was amazing - best mussels I've ever had (and I've had a lot!) And the funnel cake dessert was great too. Plus amazing wine (petit bourgeois sauvignon blanc). Chris was our server and was fantastic - attentive enough without being too much. The whole evening was excellent. Despite living way across the city from this neighborhood, I will be back!
author: Danielle C.

description:
Everything was awesome. Had oysters (fanny bay, Idk how to spell them but they were big and delicious) and a burger. Burger is on the small side for 16 dollars but it was quality and came with a deep fried pickle (a first for me). Blood orange soda was a good choice too. 

Brass tables and mason jars for water...all around a cool little spot. My only complaint was the music from the kitchen bleeding into the floor music. Server was nice and attentive though.

Definitely a great Bernal heights eatery. Fully recommend.
author: Cooper L.

description: Amazing place with frequent menu changes. This place is really delicious. Can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Joaquin C.

description:
Before writing this review, I scrolled through the previous reviews and was a bit miffed at the *10%" of bad/displeased reviews. I tend to be one of the harder to please especially for these types of finer dining establishments but was AMAZED by the food here.

We started with the Cesar Salad with calamari and it is the best salad I've had period. The waiter highly recommended it so we had very high expectations which were easily surpassed. The dressing is apparently made individually for each salad and they apply the dressing and Parmesan to each leaf of lettuce individually before stacking it back together. Instead of hard croutons, they do this crumb topping which is tastier and easier to eat. The calamari was as tender as it was flavorful and deserves it's on paragraph.

The wife ordered the Vongole with clams which came out perfectly al dente. I ordered the cod which came on a bed of corn/bacon and it was an awesome dish as well. I wish I could describe these better but you'll just have to try yourself. 

For dessert, we got a mushroom cap creme brulee...yea....weird right???? It was fukin awesome too! So much so I ALMOST ordered a second but the pinch of my belt reminded me to refrain.

I'm going back this weekend and hope to repeat the experience again! This has become one of my top nom ethnic favorite restaurants in SF hands down.
author: Mike H.

description: Too high a price for the money, fish is not tasty, don't know what happened to the food they once did, before the fish was delicious.
author: Viviana M.

description:
Just enjoyed an amazing dinner at Red Hill Station. Four of us with different entrees
and each one was amazing. 
Will recommend to all our friends who visit SF
Coming back to the city in March and will definitely revisit.
Thank you
author: Jack B.

description: I love this place, great food, great service and it's right in my hood local.  Happy Hour specials are a delight!
author: SF L.

description: The preparations sound good and the ingredients are good quality and fresh, but the flavors are just lackluster. I've had the carbonara, the fish & chips, the ceasar salad...maybe I'm just ordering the wrong things. If you mild subtle flavors to punches of vivid flavors, this is the place for you.
author: Marina N.

description:
We came on a Sunday night so the restaurant wasn't busy. Even just with the two of us, they let us sit at the large table upstairs with a window facing the kitchen. It was quieter upstairs since we had the whole room to ourselves, and we got to see the hustle and bustle in the kitchen, so we really appreciated the staff for letting us do so. 

For starter, we had the fried smelt with pesto and Caesar salad with calamari. Boy, were they good! The pesto really cut the fishiness of the smelt along with a side salad as a palate cleanser. The calamari was piping hot when it came out, very peppery and juicy, with good texture. They did an excellent job with the calamari. The main course was clams with wine sauce. The clams were fresh and the wine sauce was a delicious broth with butter, thyme, lemon and some bits of garlic. I wanted to pick up the pan and just drink the broth by itself. Our dessert chocolate pot de creme was rich and decadent with chocolate and light and fluffy with the whipped cream on top. The bit of almond extract in it made it a little different from other pot de creme I usually get. 

Everything was delicious and the staffs were friendly and attentive. Thank you for a fabulous meal and we will definitely be back!
author: Sunny C.

description:
A neighborhood joint focusing all things seafood, this is a great place to share a meal with friends. The prices are higher than neighborhood joints of yore but the big portions make up for that. This is food you will want to share. Rather than everything being two bite "tapas" the salads are large enough to be meals themselves.

This is not fancy food, this is very basic but delicious seafood staples. The menu is not huge and if you aren't a seafood or fish fan do not come here. Ordering a salad and an entree is more than enough food for  two people.

Being gluttons we ordered too much food. They had four choices of oysters from Marin and Washington State and we got 8 at $2.50 each. They were large and fresh served with a simple mignonette.

Then we had the stuffed artichoke with bay shrimp. There was good portion of shrimp and the sauce, fresh beans and beet was a great addition but the artichoke leaves were a bit tough. Would probably skip this dish again.

Our salad  was Baby greens with lardon, fried soft boiled egg, burrata, radish, red pepper, asparagus for $13. The portion was large, the scotch egg was great, the lardon was actually just strips of bacon rather than lardons. It was a very satisfying salad.

We finished with Cod Fish and Chips, slaw, lemon aioli, fries. two pieces of cod that were crisp outside and tender inside but the batter could have used some salt.

We didn't have a reservation so sat at small counter that sits 4. There is a private dining room up a short flight of stairs. The bathrooms are no wheelchair accessible up a flight of 4 stairs and very tiny. Service was friendly and casual. The menu on the website is out of date. 

All in a good neighborhood seafood place.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
When a new place opens in your hood and everyone you don't know (because they're from other neighborhoods) shows up there to chow down, you can assume the chef has a good history. This one does, but The Missus and I waited because this place is always slammed.

We got them on Mothers' Day between the rushes. Oeufs en crocotte are basically frittatas, right? Nope. They are richer here, with yolks just slightly overdone, but considering we ordered them ay 2 p.m., not unexpected.

They have generous but not-too-big portions. The fish tacos were flaky and lovely. The slaw in the tacos was no-vinegar purple grace. 

And the waiter was perfectly non-obsequious. The elevated back room is quaint but not twee, and has better acoustics than the main floor. If you don't have a wait, go.
author: Kenny C.

description: We love both the brunch and the dinner menu here. The seafood is super fresh and everything I've ordered has been delicious.
author: Diana G.

description: So apparently this place does take reservations and if you show up in person then those online reservations bump you down. We were told it would be an hour wait...an hour and a half later I check with the hostess and she tells me they received two new reservations so ours was pushed back. How is an online reservation worth more than an in-person reservation?? What a dump.
author: Dana S.

description: I'm a Bernal Hill local and am thrilled to have such a wonderful restaurant close to home! I've been to Red Hill Station several times, and on each occasion the food was excellent and our server, Jenny (who waited on us two times), was super friendly, efficient, and always at hand when we needed something. I can't say enough good things about Red Hill so I will simply continue to show my appreciation by eating there regularly!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
This was our go to dinner spot in SF... we would drive from the sunset every week or two for a night at Red Hill Station.. Why? The food is local, fresh, unbelievably light and creative. The prices were SO reasonable for the quality of food. The menu was always changing with such interesting items that were always truly incredible. I've never had such fresh fish in my life. My boyfriends family from the South Of France came with us one night while visiting, and they were a hard crowd to please, and man  oh man, every single one of them were raving about this place. Truly one of the gems of SF and as a foodie, I would go as far to say it is one of the top 3 restaurants in the bay area. 

HIGHLY HIGHLY HIGHLY Recommend! I've never been disappointed with the service, the simple and cozy decor and most of all by the incredible food!
author: Lucy O.

description: SCAM RIPOFF! CRAB SEASON CLOSED! That's what we were told at least. "There will be no crab in your stew because the crab season is done." We came here especially to have the cioppino and I am so disappointed! It's unreal that we paid more than $120 for tomato soup with a TON of clams and mussels. There was a playing card size fish chunk and about a handful of fresh oregano s well as a small slice of garlic bread. All of the flavors were great but slightly spicy for some. Personally I prefer oregano to be taken off of the woody branches. There's nothing quite like eating a few weeds with every bite.  That might work on the tourists but you should really watch out who you lie to about the food you serve. You might just lie to the wrong person who actually has a fishing license and goes for crab.
author: Kevin C.

description: The FOOD was amazing!!!!! This will be my first stop for sure for fish and chips! I do have to note that the service was extremely bad.  We ordered another plate and she didn't place the order...we needed malt vinegar, we had to get up and ask, we needed salt, we had to get up and ask while she was on her phone and also eating her dinner.  I understand bad service when you're busy, but it wasn't and when we had to continually get up, our waitress was eating carrots and texting on her phone. Nonetheless, the food was so fricking so good we tipped over 20% and was happy when we left --- great quality great food!  A must ----
author: Honest Ratings D.

description: Hi:  I'm lucky enough to spend a couple of months in San Francisco each year. One of my first stops is Red Hill Station. The food is excellent. My favorites are the hanger steak with shrimp and fresh veggies and the vongole. Not much for desserts BUT the pot of chocolate and the crem brûlée are exceptional! It is a tiny place so go off hours or call for a reservation     .
author: Donna M.

description:
This is my second time trying this place, and both times I've been disappointed. It's unfortunate as I love seafood and live in the neighborhood. 

Service: The service was extremely slow both visits. The waitress also had inaccurate information about wait time. She said ten minutes, but we ended up waiting over 30. We were seated in this awkward bar area in front of kitchen where I could barely get into my seat because it was so close to the couple next to us (and I'm not a big person). The waitress didn't have enough space to even place the dishes in front of us - she has to slide them down the bar, which was a bit strange. We didn't get any food besides bread until 50 minutes after we were seated. We ordered oysters, and those didn't come until our entrees were ready. 

Food: The food wasn't bad but nothing stood out. Some was over-salted, and other items were under-seasoned.

Highlight: The helper/bus person was really professional and took up most of the slack of the waiters. He came to check on us often and kept a really positive attitude servicing all of the tables that night. I even saw him help with shucking the oysters after the waiter was completely failing (waiter was basically stabbing the oysters and seemed like he had never done it before although he was there the first time I visited).

Overall underwhelmed with the experience. The place isn't expensive, but totally not worth it for the quality of food or service.
author: Marissa H.

description:
We've been here three times and the end result is: INCONSISTENT!

Some days, your cioppino comes with crab legs...some days, it doesn't.

Some days, you get bread and olives...some days, you have to request them.

Some days, your food comes out in a timely fashion...some days, you may wait as long as 45 minutes.

All days, the waitstaff are incredibly slow and don't seem to care about the customers -- unless their buddies come in, which makes service grind to a halt.

It wasn't until the couple next to us informed our group that Taylor, the owner/chef, decided to go from working all opening hours to just 3-4 nights a week, that we figured out the dirty secret.  The other days, the scrubs working in the kitchen are just horrible and don't care about the food they are plating.

If you want to open your own restaurant, the business is tough with horrible hours -- and you need to be there EVERY DAY at least for the first year.

THE SECRET: Phone ahead and find out if Taylor is cooking that day.  If not, RUN AWAY!
author: Louis A.

description: Wow!  Just wow!  Came here with friends and trust their choices.  This place hit it right on every note.  Maybe because I had not read anything about this place, nor seen it featured in Check Please.  Lots of seafood and fish to choose, either tartare, grilled, with linguine or in a cioppino.  Dishes are seasonal.  My halibut was served with a bagnet vert, heirloom tomatoes and kumquats.  The cioppino all about the sauce, rich and savory with lots of bread for soaking.  We finished with a pot de creme and the desert special, coronets filled with cream and zabaglione.  The latter definitely worth saving room for.
author: Kristin U.

description:
Overpriced small portions in a pretentious atmosphere with unacceptably slow service. My wife and I agree that they must not have put in our orders for a good 25 minutes after we ordered. I don't get it, we arrived and the place was basically empty today. We ordered our food and an orange juice, the waiter brings us 3 olives (seriously three olives between two people. wtf) to tide us over and a half full glass of orange juice. We proceed to wait well over 30 minutes for an ahi tuna salad and a stuffed artichoke, neither requiring extensive prep.

By the time the food arrived we were on our second plate of 3 olives, my wife had long ago finished the juice and the waiter had finally offered to bring us a plate of bread. A $50 lunch bill for two simple dishes including a forgettable $20 lunch ahi tuna salad with a meager portion of ahi. I was halfway through the salad when our waiter offered pepper for the salad. Un-freaking-believable. 

Yet another overpriced restaurant in SF that walks the trendy high-class walk but and fails to deliver on it's end of the deal. There are too many of these pretentious crap restaurants in this city, I will not be returning to this one.
author: Adam G.

description:
What a delicious experience. The Ceviche was to die for. And I'm always down for good cod!

It's an intimate yet simple place that offers
A very high end experience in a casual setting. 

Not to mention close to home so that is awesome!
author: James V.

description:
Sunday, I checked out this little Bernal gem... FINALLY. 
First off, the second we walked in, the energy from our server, Chris, was welcoming and straight up poppin! He was great. He was able to answer all my seafood questions and accomadated our needs before we even had to ask. He was always one step ahead of us! My only regret was not listening to him when he recommended we order a carafe instead of glasses of wine. Shame on us.  ALWAYS TRUST YOUR SERVER PEOPLE. :)

The atmosphere was bright and very San Francisco. 

We enjoyed two of each oyster; AMAZING and shucked properly. No grit at all. The price shocked me. So INEXPENSIVE. 
The mussels with sausage, in a  lime broth with cream and cilantro...THE BEST. 
The dungeness crab sandwich and the salad that came with, also  mouthwatering!

I am a Bernal neighbor and the hours, staff, menu and decor of this place fit all my wants out of a dining experience. 

Two thumbs up!!!!!!!!!
author: Rachel W.

description:
We went for Valentine's Day dinner. Reservation for 7:30, got there at 7:35, and as suspected, had to wait about 15 minutes from that point for our table. We have never been able to get seated on time, I wish they would figure out a system for this. In any case, the gentleman offered to open our bottle of wine but we didn't want to open the bottle for dinner while we were standing awkwardly between the beer on tap and a couple having their dinner. We thought we would start with something else first. He gave us the drink menu and asked what we would like. We each got a glass of prosecco and patiently waited for our table to open up. Two appetizers, entrees, and a dessert later, we are brought the bill. We were charged $14 for the prosecco. It's not a HUGE deal, but when we have to wait yet again for a reserved table, it just doesn't rub us the right way to be charged for drinks that we are offered. The three other times this happened, we were kindly offered a drink on the house. 

To end on a positive note, the food is delicious as always. I think they can work on improving a few things though.
author: Sofia M.

description: Food was quite delicious, three starts for feeling a little crammed at the small table for two, that gets immediately overwhelmed with just two serving plates.
author: I S.

description: I've been to Red Hill Station twice now. The ambiance are cozy and friendly, and the space very open and intimate. The staff was courteous and friendly each time, they made great recommendations and knew the menu well.  They specialize in fish and have a limited and low-risk selection (cod, salmon, mussels).  The flavor combinations were remarkable, well researched, but not earth shattering.  There could have been more effort on the vegetable and accoutrements selection.  A great place for a comfortable and cozy family dinner.  Bread was great and their honey balsamic dressing a treat.
author: Stefan R.

description: Great salads and super friendly staff :) I had the grilled tuna and it was spectacular. They have good drinks and they do brunch :3
author: Jesse H.

description:
One of my friends took us (birthday girls) here and it came highly recommended from someone who knew the owner. I'm always game at visiting new places and I haven't really ventured out to Bernal Heights before.  And of course, we had a reason to celebrate.

It was a small intimate place, already buzzing busy early on a Friday night.  So make sure you have reservations.  And note that they close early at 10 pm.

We were greeted with a friendly smile and our server was awesome.

One mishap was when we were being sitted - they tried to sit all 5 of us at a table for 4 by the window.  We clearly will not fit.  One of my friends had to sit with no table access while we wait for them to figure out our sitting situation.  Luckily, the table next to us were done and we were able to combine tables and had the room we needed.  And the wait for our food is really long.  That was almost annoying at the beginning but it all worked out at the end.

I had the carbonara.  This dish is heavy with a really creamy sauce.  The pasta was lined with bacon bits and bacon at the bottom, so it can get salty.  But since I like white sauce and salty and bacon, this dish was right for me.  The service size was decent too.  My other friends ordered the mussel soap and that dish was really well done as well.  The base tasted like a spicy curry soap - it was great!

We all enjoyed our dishes and the restaurant.  This will be a good date place for sure although bringing the kids here is okay too.
author: Pam S.

description: Some the kindest service and the most delicious tuna salad I've had! Very chill at 11AM with brunch and pear champagne drinks. They did a feat job on food, atmosphere, and present service :)
author: Jesse H.

description: Delicious!!!! I wish I took photos of our dishes, but we ate everything: the shrimp melt, cioppino, chocolate pudding, and mushroom crème brule. The service was equally outstanding.
author: Sasha S.

description:
The food here is unreal.

The oysters are so, so fresh and come with this crazy delicious dipping sauce. The grilled calamari salad was pretty sensational, too.

But it was the linguini vongole with clams, lemon, parsley and pangrattato that blew my mind. I absolutely adore pasta with a bit of crunch and acidity, so this dish checked all the boxes. 

My little sister also ordered the funnel cake for dessert and it was super fun and not too sweet. Highly recommend this to share with a group.

I dock a star because it was super loud on a Tuesday evening (which made intimate conversation a bit challenging) and also because the service was a bit off. We had to wait around to catch our waitress's attention several times (for wine, for an additional glass, for water, for our bill, etc), plus she spoke extra, extra slowly to my parents who speak perfect English -- it was rather offputting.

Other than that the ambiance and the adorable neighborhood make Red Hill Station a win! They just need some time to work out the kinks.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
What a wonderful new discovery in Bernal Heights:

We walked in no reservation, got two spots on counter facing the kitchen:
There is nothing better than seeing your kitchen crew smiling, and having fun while they cook up the goods:

Had amazingly fresh chucked Oysters on the half shell, mignonette ( do we have to stop at one dozen?)
Alaskan True Cod fish with  the tastiest roasted vegetables on side 
Of course they do offer the traditional  garlic white wine sauce, but why not try something you don't see often:
Mussless with chorizo cream sauce with freshly baked bread on side, they should hand you a couple of straws the sauce is that good.  

Such a sweet place!
author: Sofia D.

description:
i came here for dinner a few wks ago, and i thought it was ok.  while waiting for the rest of our party to arrive, three of us sat there, and no one came by to take drink orders for quite a while.  

we ordered a bunch of food to share, and i thought the grilled calamari salad was good, as was the fish and chips.  the cioppino was a bit too chunky for me, and i felt like i was eating seafood w/ tomato sauce rather than a soup.
author: Helen T.

description:
WHAT IS ALL THE FUSS ABOUT?

PLEASE TELL ME.

This place looked just perfect walking by, and I couldn't wait to try it. I made my honey take me here for cleaning his house, which is steps away. Each dust bunny and wall wipe was one step closer to the amazing-looking menu that made me salivate.

Then we get there at 8 for our 8 reservation. It's SRO, and the place is tiny. We're asked if we would like some wine while we wait "outside" and we agreed to the wine, but taking it outside felt awkward because we were pretty sure that's illegal. So we awkwardly clutched our glasses of unknown-priced prosecco with our butts in other clients' faces hoping to be seated soon.

At 8:25, thankfully we were finally seated for our 8, because I was about to chew my own arm off. When I said "OK" to "how are you?" and was greeted with the third degree on why only okay, I mentioned the time. We were told this was "San Francisco standard" and basically felt like we had a mini-lecture about why no SF resident should expect to be seated right at their reservation time. While I totally accept that all kinds of things are out of their control, what could have hurt about a simple apology?

Geez.

So, that's part of the service problem. The rest of the service problem is the long wait in between questions and answers, starters and mains...we waited so long for everything I felt more like a prisoner than a guest. Also apparently the wine fridge was on the fritz so we were not presented with a wine list in print, just verbal, with no prices. It's one thing to roll the dice on a $9 glass of wine, but we had no idea whether that meant $9, $11, $14....? So that was weird too. The cooler going out was beyond their control but not being able to give prices was not.

Oh yes, and let's not forget that the dude in the apron and striped pants (head chef, yes?) was hanging out with customers for 20 of those 25 minutes in the dining room and NOT cooking. Could that have been the reason for the terrible kitchen timing with everything? Are you a chef or a host? Pick, because you can't do both.

So, the food. We were pleased to find they could make the Caesar dressing vegetarian, and the Caesar was tasty and unique (crispy crumbs, no croutons) and worth $10. I ordered the cod, and my honey ordered the farro dish. Lo and behold, we got the exact same thing, only mine had cod for an extra $6, and he had slightly more veggies. Farro in brodo and summer veggies. It was good, but exactly what I'd throw together at home after a trip to Monterey Market and Monterey Fish Market. Exactly. 

I felt like I was paying to eat in my own living room. I could have grilled that squash and steamed those beans. I could also import special Italian farro. I go to restaurants to eat what I can't make or don't have time to make, so I feel kinda shorted when I'm handed Le Boring. I have the patent on Le Boring already.

They clearly were aware of how terrible they timing and everything was; they comped all our wine (4 glasses). Because of that generosity I might go back. But I won't drag my sweetie to Le Boring, which is all they have for vegetarians.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
So so good for seafood. I love they change their menus often and stay close to what's available seasonally. Their oysters are always so fresh and so good. Their calamari salad is to die for every time and last night I just tried the yellow tail tartar and it was so good as well.

The place is very low key but the food and service are excellent.
author: Nga P.

description:
This place is new, and it shows great promise but definitely needs polishing around the edges. Overall, the food was *very* good, but not consistent. Some of the dishes were out-of-this-world delicious, but others were not quite right. 

The complimentary garlicky olives served with bread were flavorful and probably are house-made. We started with a plate of oysters that were as fresh and tasty as any in the city, served with a good quantity of nice, tart mignonette. An appetizer of fried local anchovies with pesto and arugula was a great combination of flavors, but it didn't quite come off right: there was way too much pesto on the plate, and way too much dressing on the arugula; the dish was still tasty because of the fresh and perfectly cooked anchovies, but I don't think we'd order it again. As a main, my husband had a linguine with mixed shellfish, and this dish was perfect in every way -- pasta just al dente, seafood cooked just right, in a rich broth that exploded with flavor -- good enough all by itself to justify a return visit. I had ling cod in almond butter with roasted potato and vegetables; the cod was fantastic, perfectly cooked with just the right amount of sweet almond butter and toasted almonds to perfect the flavors. A single large fingerling potato was perfectly roasted. The other vegetables, though, were not right. I like my vegetables crisp, but the green beans were almost raw; by contrast the roast squash was falling apart and mushy from being roasted too long. 

The service was very friendly and helpful, but the coordination with the kitchen needs work. At a certain point, it seemed like the kitchen had finished cooking pasta, and so pasta dishes were served to one table after another. It was at least another five minutes before fish dishes started to come out of the kitchen and get served. The result was that, if everyone at your table ordered pasta, then you all got served at once; but if one of you ordered fish and the other ordered pasta, there was a long delay. This is not OK; in a restaurant at this level, the whole table needs to be served at the same time.  

The ambience and décor are Bernal Heights casual, but the prices are not. Dinner was $100 for two, not including wine.  

We loved some of the dishes so much that we will definitely go back, and would love to have a successful seafood place in Bernal. But we do hope to see them iron out some of the kinks that were so noticeable on our first visit. 

We say 3 stars now, but with clear potential to reach 4 or 5 with a bit more polish.
author: David K.

description:
I've only been there on weekends for lunch/brunch, but I LOVE this place. Food is amazing, staff is awesome, all in all one of my favorite places in SF. A bit on the pricey side, but you get incredibly fresh and high quality seafood, which makes it totally worth it.

Food / Drink: 
- Mussels to die for
- Whole crab is beautifully served and oh so tasty
- Grilled squid was light and delicious Mediterranean style 
- Great wine list (love the Sancerre)
- Bread was sooo gooood 

Service:
- fantastic every time, friendly and fun staff
- friends were late and they gave us a free appetizer
author: Shaelyne J.

description:
I love it. All the food has amazing rich flavor. You have to be a seafood lover to come here! (Actually that's a lie because I came here with a vegetarian and they did everything off-menu and made her the most incredible pesto pasta).

Love the oysters, the presentation, and the service. They will accommodate you and are very kind.

The space is kind of small, so it's best to make a reservation in order to get seated.
author: Carleen W.

description:
I was very pleased to discover this hidden gem. The restaurant isn't easy to spot - even if you're looking for it - due to its unpretentious exterior.

The menu is simple (which I love) yet sufficiently  diverse. I had the pesto linguine w prawns; it was delicious, balanced, and the portion size was perfect: not too big not too small. The one imperfection is that the dish was excessively oily, but not enough to detract from how tasty it was regardless.

Service was on point: friendly and professional. The interior is cute/cozy with an open kitchen. Loved this place, will definitely return.
author: Sergey P.

description:
Well, it's a seafood place, right? And they serve oysters on Cortland which is nice. But when I asked the waiter to tell me about the oysters, he was seriously caught off guard. He was clueless and could only tell me about their sizes. He was a little absent too.

Regarding the restaurant, the food is decent but a bit heavy handed. The tuna tartare was tasty but it was more of a ceviche and had way too much basil and olive oil.

Hey, get an awning. You're hard to find when driving through busy Cortland!
author: Rude G.

description: LOVE IT!! ALL MY STARS! The service and atmosphere are amazing, and the food is the best in bernal. i love it all the time.
author: Jorge C.

description:
I like the idea of a neighborhood seafood joint that we can walk to on a whim or planned night out. Red hill station started off strong with great service and a deft hand in the kitchen.
